name: Tom Clancy’s The Division™
description: After a deadly pandemic sweeps through New York, it's up to Agents to save what remains. Complete missions, explore the Dark Zone, and fight back enemy factions alone or with 3 friends. Experience a full endgame offering you new PvP and PvE modes.

reviews.review_text: When The Division was teased for people to get them hyped, the game looked amazing. They promised so much and gave a hell of a show when promoting the game. So we waited. We sat on our hands in order to keep from clapping at the idea of being able to roam around in a world so vast and changing, acquiring loot, meeting friends, and forming expansive teams along the way. The game looked awesome and boasted a lot of things to occupy your time. Then....it released.   Graphics were dumbed down. Gameplay was repetitive. There was no guild/clan features. Matchmaking was buggy. Weapon and Gear bonuses and stats were incorrect. The plot of this game shifted from fighting in an environment that was devastated by a virus to more of a giant bug collection where you fumbled and crawled your way through all the pain brought on by the issues in the game just to experience what it was like to level up. And Ubisoft/Massive did little to help. Even now, after rolling out patch 1.2, they have broken more than they fixed. In fact we're all sure that they fixed nothing and uploaded a compiled file of bugs into the game instead. So let's list what we have here. Please read this carefully before you ever consider purchasing....or even playing for free.   Pros ::  - The Game looks gorgeous - The equipment system is lovely - The personal appearance is pretty entertaining - Static clutter and objects are plenty and not stationary. (Shoot that rat. Smack that lamp) - The sounds are great. The ambience is just intense with headphones, which is good. - There are plenty of missions to choose from for the first 30 hours - The weapon modification system is nice  - The gunplay is pretty decent  Cons :: (Hold on to your hat) - There are bugs. Bugs everywhere. I mean seriously, this game is made of bugs. - There is no customer service - Patches break a LOT more than they fix - Gameplay is VERY repetitive - NPCs can shoot through walls - Players get locked out of instances - Upon joining a match, there is a high chance you will fall through the map, get teleported out, and fall again. - Graphical bugs left and right. You'll see the poly blocks floating around where fog should be, etc.  - The storyline is extremely boring - The game is nothing like the trailers. It has been dumbed down - The content you see from the E3 promotions? Totally inaccurate - The NPCs are all pretty much the same, only some have flamethrowers and some have armor.  - The loading screens are EXCESSIVE. Every single thing you do prompts a loading screen. If you join a group from matchmaking, you load for 2 minutes. They can kick you during that 2 minutes. So your load screen resets before you even load in and, what, you're dropped where they SHOULD have been. Then it teleports you back to a safehouse and you load for another 2 minutes. Even for High end PCs, the load times are far too long and there is a sickening amount of things that call for them. - The Matchmaking, frankly, sucks. It will not match you with people within the range of your gear. So if you're trying to gear up, it just tosses you in an open slot. And if that group is geared and they don't like that you're not, you get booted. This makes joining groups for getting into the DZ and missions in order to even get gear HARD. Of course, you get kicked and get to see those neat load screens. - The latency is iffy. I personally run on a fiber connection and the amount of lag that I see is ridiculous. You'll watch people scoot down walls. You'll see yourself teleport several feet from where you took cover. You'll unload 4 complete magazines into an enemy and do no damage only to see the damage pop up on him 20 seconds later after he's killed your teammate. Etc. - The cover system is ALMOST acceptable, but it's not. Having your cover system default to the same button as your roll button is just bad. You'll try to move into cover and roll right past it. Or attept to roll away from a grenade damage zone and take cover instead thus killing you. - A lot of the NPCs are overpowered. This game is punishment if you have to fight a group of NPCs that have shotguns. Not only can they 1 shot you, but they have armor. And they don't take cover and play smart. They RUSH you without regard of their own health. You have to pray that you and your group (if you have one) can kill them before they get close.  - The DZ is boring. It's a lot of running around, shooting NPCs to get another level ladder crawling up, hoping you get loot. Then you get it, try to get back to extract it, and bam : some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that is leagues above you kills you JUST to kill you. But, the DZ is one of the better places to get gear. Well tough ♥♥♥♥. Then again not a lot of people go Rogue since there's no benefit from it. The DZ is just boring. - It's also impossible to get a good DZ group unless you just run into someone in there and they decide to join you. Matchmaking is useless for this. Seeing as you cannot matchmake inside the DZ makes it even more useless. You had best hope you find another lonely soul that doesn't just shoot you on sight. - There is no endgame. Once you hit level 30 and fill out your equipment with Highend equipment....eh. You can go after and hunt the gearsets, but that's really just doing the same mission over and over and over and over and over and over and hoping that if something drops it's not the EXACT SAME THING you already have. Besides that you get a couple of dailies. Once you complete those (About 15 minutes) you're too bored to continue playing. - There is no clan/guild system. You can't do something as basic as create a clan/guild name, invite friends, and have a system to talk to people when in game. Oh no. you have to relay your conversations through Uplay IF you can meet anyone that plays in game....because, really, the game is pretty much dead.  - Lastly for my list is that Ubisoft/Massive doesn't care. They promoted this game. They promised so much. They have so many resources available to make this an amazing experience...but they don't. Bugs that are gamebreaking are left in the game. Right now if you join a group, your UI doubles and you can't use it. This has led to people losing items. Gear. Skills being changed mid fight and wiping a group, etc. Where is the company? Where is the customer support? They're nowhere to be found because they have the money and that's the end of it.   This is an example of a DECENT enough game that's good for wasting time, if you're bored and have nothing better to do, that could have been great. Ubisoft/Massive failed this title. They got everyones hopes up, sold the game, and backed off. When other games do this, they get taken down from Steam and there is a widespread refund spree, but not in this case. People are still PRAYING that it gets as good as it should be and hold on by the skin of their teeth...but it won't. It's like they have 5 people who work on this title...2 days a week...for a few hours...and only if they want to. They let the community down. They let the Tom Clancy name down. They let every single person who spent $60 on this game down. And not because they didn't give us a decent platform to start with...but because once they realized they messed up they quit caring about it and us.   The Divison has been broken since day one. Almost everything they promised they removed. It's not as lush, vibrant, and expansive as they promised it was. We got the Bait and Switch. Now it's struggling to maintain an 8000 playerbase. So before you spend your hard earned money on this title...just don't. This is the game that COULD HAVE BEEN amazing, but it wasn't. This is the game that robbed us of our enthusiasm. This is the game that is dying a very sad and lonely death. You can argue that if you get an hour playtime for every dollar that you spent on a game makes it worth the money, but it doesn't. At 70+ hours, I saw all this game had to offer and am just..disappointed.

When it has all been said and done, I think most reviews and the criticisms of the The Division are warranted.   To sum it up in a nutshell, The Division is to gaming history, the most wasted potential videogame of all-time. It has an excellent premise, but it is poorly executed in not only gameplay, but story, environmental and level design, and NPC interactions, or lack thereof.   The lack of an anti-cheat system leaves you wondering what Massive Entertainment and Ubisoft were thinking during the planning, strategy, and conceptualization stages of development. Not only do hackers or players without a conscience continue to exploit this game, Massive has denounced a statement saying that an anti-cheat system is basically out of the question because 'we would need to build this game from the ground up again.'  Unlike some other The Division early adopters, I was never butt-hurt by the E3 gameplay, or the mad and sickening hype. Unfortunately for me, I do not understand why some blatantly obvious game designs were not in this game.   The streets of New York City is barren, even as pre-apocalyptic or apocalyptic world. Ubisoft and Massive should have opted for a ficticious city instead of a realistic New York. Trading a videogame fantasy world for a more realistic one is one of the major drawbacks to The Division's level and environmental design. The problem with this is, you have very little to work with because the developer tried too hard to be true to New York City's landscape, leaving little to the imagination.  The loot system is severely flawed. The 'Gear Rating System' Massive has in place is misleading. For example, a player can have a gear rating of 204, but have less damage per second, health, or skill power than a player with a gear rating of 190. Basically put, the gear rating is skewed and distorted.   I may not know everything about MMO-like or MMO videogames, but I have played my fair share. In that, I have some credibility as a gamer who once appreciated MMOs and especially MMO-RPGs like Dark Age of Camelot, World of Warcraft (golden days), Warhammer: Age of Reckoning, Guild Wars 1 and 2, and modern ones like The Secret World. While I draw comparisons, I want to say that the MMOs I mentioned at least tried to bring in new game mechanics and MMO worlds that brought 'something new' and most importantly, fun gameplay and loot. The Division features loot as guns and 'gear,' which in some sense it does well. The character design is pretty to look at and the clothing, equipment, and armor all look great aethestically but nothing more.   The Division relies heavily on crafting and farming Pheonix credits which you would then trade in to a vendor to purchase new weapons, equipment, or blueprints. At the moment, players have to rely too heavily on crafting gear in order to take on the only incursion we have in the game. Daily assignments are few and far in between, so you would have to complete the daily assignments for Pheonix credits every day in order to rack up hundreds of credits to purchase the gun or blueprint that you need to pack any kind of punch for an incursion. *Massive did state with a recent update that they are attempting to remedy this issue. We will see about that.  MMOs have instances or dungeons and this is typically the meat of the endgame where players farm for loot or gear. Ubisoft/Massive 'gave' us an Incursion called 'The Falcon: Lost' as a free update. This is the problem and plague of the current situation of the videogame industry. 'FREE UPDATES' and what is it, really? The base game of The Division before the Incursion update was barebones as you can get. Very little content, as in, a few missions, and nodes on the map that would give you vertigo, thinking about Assassin's Creed's nodes on the map that induced OCD. This is probably the most shallow aspect of the game besides its story and NPC interaction in story mode.   On another note, The Division lacks any sense of threat. You never feel like the city is lost in shambles; not even in the Dark Zone, which is suppose to be the darkest corners of the game. Like I have said before, the game design falls short immediately when the player does not feel any sense of threat, urgency, and motivation to bring cause and effect to attention. Because simply, there is none. And that in itself is a sad fact of the game.   The Dark Zone is lackluster, full of hackers, and wasted potential. In DZ, you are doing the same thing over and over, and if you are expecting the dynamic of human vs human or PVP interaction in the same vein of DayZ and like games, you will be very disappointed. There are too many hackers. The punishment and reward system is severely flawed and it does not reward co-op players. One simple rule, as with past MMOs or MMO-like games is simply this: ADD A PVP TOGGLE ON OR OFF OPTION. It is that fvking simple.  You may be wondering why I have invested so many hours in The Division and have the audacity to 'thumbs down' the game in such hypocritical fashion. It's quite simple. I review games after I have given enough game time, especially when it is an MMO-like-style game. It is only fair. After a handful of updates with the addition of the 'free' incursion, and Massive's inability to resolve the glaring issues in the game, I cannot recommend it to anyone at this price point. I cannot even recommend the game for $1 because it would be a waste of your time. You are better off spending your time doing other things. Seriously. I mean this sincerely.  I could keep writing, going in to 'massive' detail about what should and should not be in The Division, but it would be an overwhelming task that only my mind can understand at the moment. Most players would agree that The Division is a huge wasted potential. The proportionality of negative to positive reviews is not only valid, but almost sound if you were to ever experience such disappointment without reconciliation of the fact you just wasted not only your hard earned cash, but also your valuable time.  Verdict: Not recommended. Avoid until Massive and Ubisoft implements an anti-cheat system and addresses and resolves several issues in the game. While I understand this is Massive's first roundabout at a game such as this one. It comes with its own challenges and complexities which deviate from the standard and traditional single-player and multiplayer affair. Even though I cut Massive some slack on that front, there are far too many minor and major issues Massive continues to overlook, which leaves me to question their approach and strategy to fix some of the game's many problems.

DO NOT BUY  Riddled with gamebreaking bugs and hackers.  No hotfixing (exploits being in the game for weeks). No proper anti-cheat system is implemented. No testing before release. No endgame content. No reliable way of getting new gear/upgrades. Ubisoft/Massive blames the playerbase for their own obvious mistakes.  Each patch seem to take away from the player. No communication with the community. Customer support is non-existant.

One of the best games i had ever played, amazing graphics and environment, more then 500 hours on this. Played mostly solo because my friends simply didnt had the patience to understand this game mechanics and gear system, playing solo it was painfull ... its not fun being chased around by groups of players just killing you just because they could. 1.3 almost destroyed this game, and the devs saw that ... and what they did on this game is nothing short of amaizing, they actually listened to the people playing it and fixed most of the isues, respecting what the community was saying. 1.4 its a revolution on the game mechanics, and made the game balanced even for solo players like me. And now ... 1.5 and survival. Survival its amazing ... everything that it didnt matter in game before it matters now ... water, food, meds ... the gear that was cosmetic only now has a purpose ... starting outside the DZ and making your way there it actually feels challenging . Even in this time the devs are making questionaires on what the community would like to see in The Division, the devs could have simply let the game die ... but they didnt. I give them respect for that, and for listening to the ones playing it accepting all the critics and improving the game vastly. I was waiting for this for my review. If you get this ... make shure you get the gold edition with the season pack, its half the price now and survival alone is worth it. But hey ... i know nothing about games, im just a noob having fun. And this game just got fun !

I did the unthinkable...I pre-ordered a ubisoft game...I KNOW I KNOW, no need to kill me...the thing is..until last week...this game was just awful, almost unplayble EVEN with friends which was very sad, I used to play it..every once in a while for 1 or 2 hours, BUT NOW after patch 1.4 I think this game is ALMOST ready to be played daily by the people that like it's style,the game still has it's bugs,which ubisoft will try to fix later on,there might still be a few exploits and all but not that many,after patch 1.4 I think this game is starting to go on the right path, for once I can say I'm proud of pre-ordering from Ubisoft,altough after 'No Man's' Lie', I'll never pre-order ANYGAME ever again, for safety.  Just so you guys know how playable the game is now compared to launch and up to 1.3, I bought the season pass yesterday because I knew I'd have FUN playing this game so It was a nice deal and the Season pass is almost as expensive as the game,so yeah.   I rate this game (currently 1.4 patch) a 7/10, enjoyable with friends,fun and challenging when you are alone. Cons:The game needs EVEN more backstory to it,I find this whole scenario fascinating, to the point where I want to learn more more and more. Playing in the Dark Zone alone,is very risky, there needs to be a way so that if you are solo in the DZ,you get a small buff or something to help you run away from groups of rogues,maybe if you are alone you move (Insert percentage here) faster than everyone else. Pros: With friends AND the Underground DLC, this game has a 8/10 level of replaybility and daily play so you know grab a few friends and play it.Incursions which have very nice loot and daily rewards encourage partnership between players,which in turn makes making friends easier.  That is all,my honest opinion,I've hated this game and I felt ripped off by Ubisoft, but now I can say that I will get my money back in playtime. Thank you all for reading.

I'll go as far to say this is the biggest disappointment since BRINK. So much potential, and a great foundation, but it's another AAA title released with little-to-no content, and you will likely have to spend over $100 to get a decent experience with future DLC. Not only that, but there are so many stupid bugs that are still in the game that SHOULDN'T be after an alpha and two betas.   There are also cheaters around like mad in the Dark Zone.  A beautiful world... but it's so barren. There's almost no reason to free roam the map, as there are no real random events on the map. I just can't help but feel disappointed with what could have been.  As of now, stay away and avoid like the plague. I usually don't preorder games, for this reason, but they somehow convinced me to get hyped for this game after the beta. My mistake.

They have found the formula! It took them until patch 1.4 to do it, but this game is great now!  Forget everything you heard or saw at release. If you're looking for a looter-shooter that actually has tactical team gameplay and gets more fun as you increase the difficulty, there is nothing better out there right now.

The game looks fantastic. It runs well. And that's about all we can hope for anymore isn't it?  Let me tell you something. You've already played this game. Probably a dozen times. I know I have. You've cleared the building before. You've swapped your gear for more gear. You've opened the shiny loot container for a bandage that you can't carry. There is nothing new or innovative about this game. It's the same old thing in a new shiny package. It has crafting. Of course it does. Everything has to have crafting these days. Lots of long runs to the next objective. Cause none of us have played any hiking simulators in the past few years. Talent system with special powers? Obviously. Special powers in a   cover-based tactical   3rd person shooter...  The gameplay is extremely easy and I find it deeply unsatisfying. The overwhelming majority of quests are kill quests of one degree or another that provide little challenge. The third person view and cover based mechanics directly clash with each other. It's not a shooter. It's Zeus hurling lightning bolts. You can see everyone at all times, all their movements, preparing to throw a grenade, when they pop up, when they go down. You can shoot with astounding accuracy over cover without exposing yourself. And should an enemy actually be hidden, don't worry, theres a superpower that gives you xray vision.   On the point of upgrading gear, they've found a way to make it even less satisfying than its been in all the other games we've been playing since WoW. They seperated the gear with stats from the gear that alters appearance. Ignorning that the majority of the 'appearance gear' looks largely similar, now you have two gear screens that you have to maintain and more nonsense sort. What that achieved for me is making it so that I completely ignore my characters appearance. Well done.   Personally, I don't think this game deserves the hype or the success it's recieving. But that's the state of gaming today isn't it? As much as I dislike this game, it's probably going to be one of the best titles to come out of the next month or two.   With the recommend buttons looming below my ever-growing review I'm forced to concede that if you are as disillusioned as I am about the state of gaming these days then you must admit this game does not deserve your support. But what else is there? If you are interested in this game and are willing to knowingly pay more than it is probably worth... then it's ok. It's ok because we don't have a better benchmark right now.   tl;dr This game is like another Wal-Mart popping up in your home town. You know it's not good. You'd rather it wasn't there. But Wal-mart has shiny graphics and it runs well on your PC. So it's not the worst thing in the world to shop there. But your money is better spent elsewhere.  *edit - some commas and some words
'Player experience is and always will be at the center of everything we do and we are constantly looking at ways to improve it.' -Ubisoft  Yeah, right.

I think the biggest flaw this game has is not explaining very well what it is.  If you played EverQuest and lost your corpse at the bottom of a well, have enjoyed raiding on a WOW pvp server and getting corpse camped, spent time in 0.0 space in EVE Online getting blobbed by goons and doing calculus in spreadsheets to determine builds or like just like a Diabloesque never ending loot grind then you'll probably enjoy the Division like I do because at its core this game is a Third Person RGP with many MMO elements and influences.   You'll have to grind for gear and the RNG is real. You might farm the same bosses for hours to obtain the BiS slot items and rolls. The incursions (raids) are tough and you'll need to follow a shifting meta of BiS gear, group up and learn game mechanics to be successful. Sometimes the content and the meta to beat it isn't very fun but that's the nature of the beast.  Just like any MMO if you try to PUG difficult content you're going to end up being match made into a group of Leroy Jenkins's and have a bad time. This means that some content/items are simply out of reach for some players due to bad RNG, not having a group or just being really bad at avoiding red circles on the ground.  The game has a core game play component (the dark zone) that is a PvPvE zone. The best loot drops in the dark zone and it's the most efficient place to play, however, it seems like the current generation of gamers don't mesh well with PvPvE so before you buy this game you need to acknowledge that you'll be killed in the dark zone for your gear, rogues will cut your extract rope and steal your loot and they'll shoot you just for the hell of it; especially if you're solo. Most importantly you need to know that this isn't griefing; these are game play mechanics.    There are some legitimate complaints here re: stat and item scaling and lack of (efficient) farm PvE content but it is not fair to compare this to No Man's Sky at all. The game world is big and immersive with an incredible about of attention to detail. I have over 500 hours and still see and hear new things regularly. If you just run from waypoint to waypoint or fast travel you'll miss a lot of little details.  Lastly the developers have acknowledged that getting 1 shot isn't that fun and the scaling is a bit silly at the latest stages of the game. They have just added a Player Test Server and are working on a major game play patch called 1.4. You can login and play and see changes happening on a weekly basis and they are addressing most of the major issues with stat and item scaling.  Overall I've greatly enjoyed my time in The Division and hope this gives you a better idea of what to expect if you decide to purchase.

Alright so I've been playing this game for awhile. Definitely had its ups and downs. BUT I finally feel like the game is balanced, and things actually make sense now. Wish patch 1.4 came a lot earlier than it did, because a lot of my old friends from launch are no longer around.   Obviously with a game like this, it will always be quite difficult to play solo in the DZ. But if you choose your gear set and talents properly, you can actually somewhat manage. With the way the game currently is, I can reccommend it. Play with friends if you can though.

Yet another open world Ubisoft game that somehow manages to ruin the idea of exploring an open world through generic side-quests, an overzealous minimap/waypoint system, and the idea that the main goal of playing an open world game is collecting 50 of whatever.  Please... for the sake of your art and tech guys, who have realised a beautiful and visually interesting postapocalypic Manhattan, take a look at Bethesda's games for how to make open world titles that immerse and engage the player rather than make everything a chore. As a player there's a massive frustration in seeing something that could have been an absorbing and amazing game reduced to tedium by the design rather than technical or artistic limitations.  This is before we get to the darkzone stuff which is meant to be endgame, but there's still some clear design confusion over whether this is meant to be a long-term MMO or short-term story with multiplayer tacked on. It's a decent concept but at the moment broke in the implementation, and quickly becomes a grind with a clear risk/reward issue around going rogue. In terms of multiplayer (and overall game) longevity, this is Borderlands - there's some, but nobody still plays Borderlands now, right?  In summary, this is not a *bad* game, but comes frustratingly - visually and technically - close to being an amazing one, then is massively let down by game design to below mediocrity.

- Early-access of The Division 2.0 with AAA price tag - Wait, what?! With all the hours poured in you downvote the game?  - Yes, I do   Review v 1.1    1. World   This stunning hand-crafted NY city is as beautiful as it is empty. When you grinding towards level 30, you are completing unique story missions along with absolutely unimaginative obligatory side missions. Upon completion of all the activities  (takes about 14 hours if you do not rush anything)  you are stuck with absolutely useless NY city. There are no real random or special encounters on the streets of NY after you reach level 30. It feels empty and I wonder why the put so many effort in decorating city which is 15-hours-long-and-the-gone.   2. Mechanics   There are a lot of bugs and inconsistencies all over The Division and they all add up to the overall frustrating experience we get as an endgame. From exploits that let players get the loot instantly and then troll the dark zone newbies to bugs with perks and talents, jammed guns and skills delay / miscasts / double cooldowns and so on. Sadly, there is nothing behind that cinematic beauty we have been fed up with but poor execution. I will not be detailed here as there is so much broken in the game that I doubt they can fix it even in a year.   3. Endgame   In my opinion the endgame in The Division is a non-stop mindless grindfest for items that you don’t care about. Maybe a little PvP on top but that’s it. You get the best gear and then you kill all the weaker agents in the dark zone simply because almost everyone are within the same 161+ gear score bracket.   3.1 Loot   Massive is simply screwing people about loot. I do accept that this type of game involves grind but not of extent that you farm dark zone, missions for tens of hours so you get   nothing   better in return. There are different kinds of problems with the loot but the core thing is it   not feels rewarding at all  .    3.1.1 Grinding   Believe me when I say this is a mindless grind. It really doesn’t matter whether you exploit or do not  (so you will have to waste enormous amount of time as I did)  it will take a lot of hours for you to get something useful. It would have been a bit better if you get a truck of useless stuff and then you make something useful from it. But no, the equipment is scarce even though it is complete crap in most of the cases. The   wow effect   will instantly vanish when you see that the first high-end / set item you get is actually worse than your epic purple. And the second, and then the third. Damn, what’s wrong with this game? Have they checked out Diablo 3 and Destiny lessons learned?  Want to add about Division Tech grind. Yes, you can farm it only in the dark zone and it will take ages for you to farm it even with boosted chance of drop because crafting takes so much of it for each ♥♥♥♥ roll you do that you can spend entire weekend for div tech farm ending up with nothing.   3.1.2 Crafting   Generally, crafting it is not a bad thing. Bad thing here is that it is the most reliable way of getting decent equipment. And the most reliable way is full of random. Random stats, random effects, random talents with 90% of them being completely useless. I am extremely lucky that I get best-in-slot guns after 10 to 20 rolls but still I have that amount of hours in because I farm materials for these rolls. I have seen people that exploited hell out of Hornet, Bullet King etc., rolled for hundreds of high-end vector and did not get a single decent one. That’s simply frustrating. With 1.1 update they aimed to divert people from crafting through.. increasing amount of materials required to craft. Well, that’s cool but it is not punishing at all for exploiters or for those who are already in decent gear (so they farm high-ends for materials) – it is punishing for those who are still level up. You can get decently geared in a day (of playtime) if you have a good team but that is almost a month for casual players  (assuming 10 hours/ week or less) . Okay, you trying to show people that crafting is not the best way but are there any others really? Sure you can farm DZ for high-ends quickly reaching a certain gear score within 180ish bracket and then slowly making it into 190ish bracket. You can farm Incursion for the 214 gear  (challenge mode) . With a good team you can do it in 25 mins but I guarantee you will fail at least several times beforehand.    3.1.3 Talents and stats   There are  a lot of useless talents and stats  on both weapons on gear  (say hi to additional experience gain for level 30 characters, but wait, do they need one after they reached the level cap already?) . There are a lot of stats that really doesn’t significantly add up to your survival skills. Useful stats and talents compromise something like 10% of all currently in-game. Weapons are simply imbalanced - there are obvious choices for PvP and PvE .   3.1.4 Gear Score   This is innovation made life so easier for.. who exactly? You think that higher gear score is better? Higher rarity of item is better? Well, think again. Same mistake was done in Diablo 3 before Reaper of Souls and here we go again. I have 191gs set items   WAY BETTER  than 240gs set items. And that’s not some weird one case – I still have a few 191 pieces I cannot improve after don’t-know-how-many times passed Challenging Incursion.   3.2 Skills and builds   I have experimented with builds for a while but there is nothing in game that really rewards altering your playstyle. Aside from playing technician on Incursion there is no point of other build than “SMG + M1A First Wave, Firearms + Stamina, Pulse + Heal + Survivor Link”. If you claim that your build is better,– you simply haven’t met SMG-M1A build of your level yet. Spend several hours tweaking your playstyle and equipment and you will see that there are clearly a set of skills that are better than others. There is no real balance here and the game is constantly pushing you to a certain way of playing. I have to mention  “exploit cover”  skill, or how Massive calls it – mobile cover. This skill needs to be deleted from the game (sorry, 1% of players) for the greater good.    4. Dark Zone   PvP experience at its finest - thought MassiSoft.   4.1 Area   While it looks big at first, you will soon realize how small it is. You will, literally, farm 4-5 spawn points for materials and div tech all days long. Shoot, extract, run, repeat. The chance of good drop is so small that you can play for 100 hours and get just a couple of decent items. And all glitches and exploits apply to this zone as well.   4.2 Gear score brackets   This system would be nice if we had more gs brackets. Currently, guys with 161gs  (~30 hours of play)  and 222gs  (~250 hours of play assuming best-in-slot gear)  are placed within the same zone and so the is how Massive defines PvP experience. A one-shot zone for everyone.   4.3 Cheaters   C’mon, Ubisoft. You are doing this to us over and over again. Anti-cheat system doesn’t exist in Ubisoft titles and this game follows the rule.   This list is in no way an exhaustive list of flaws but it provides the same impression I have about this game. Overall the  game is 5/10 at most. . Hope my review helps.   Disclaimer:  With all the words said, I still appreciate the work done and I know that developing games is not an easy job. It is just frustrating to see that another promising title turned into who-knows-what due to poor execution. Let's not be too harsh on developers - let them try to fix it.  Ubisoft is very good at marketing and innovating but they suck at execution so much that you will hate yourself for buying their game. Again.  Out of chars.

I have to start by saying that I really did enjoy, I like the game's story and I thought that the missions itself were fun...   The end game content and the PvP is what is the bane of the game and has essentially made this game broken. What is worse is that every time the end game and PvP gets adjusted it get even worse.   I have many issues with the game and one of them being the crafting system for level 30 gear. When the game first came out the number of lower end material need to make one higher end material was the following; 5 green to make 1 blue and 5 blue to make 1 yellow. After the incursion patch and is still 10 green to make 1 blue and 15 blue to make 1 yellow. You probably thinking that this change does not sound so bad and it would have been fair if Ubisoft had adjusted the rate at which you get material, but no Ubisoft made it worse. Each material point on the map now only gave 2-3 items per box at a refresh rate of 4 hours per box. This was changed from the 2-3 items per box at a refresh rate of 1 hour per box. Also the weapon breakdown went from 2-3 material per item broken down to 1 material per item broken down. This change had two effects, one it made crafting into a grind and a joke as all the stats on an item you craft are random and you can only readjust a single stat. You’re probably thinking big deal why don’t you just make another item to reroll the stats, that a great idea if Ubisoft hadn’t jacked up all the prices for crafting. What cost 3 weapon material 5 electronic material now cost 8 weapon material and 6 electronic materials. The second effect is that it screws over legitimate players mostly. The cheater/hacker/exploiters don't need to craft anything, they just run the incursion on hard or run around screwing legitimate players in the dark zone. The cheater/hacker/exploiters are the ones running around with the best gear and killing people at random because they think it is fun.  Another issue is the vendors. 90% of the time the vendors just sell the same stuff over and over again and they don’t rotate the blueprints. Which means you can get 2 items from the new armor sets then you have to play the incursion or the challenge mission and prey that you get the piece of armor that you want. That would not be as much of an issue, if there were more ways than playing the bullet sponge filled challenge and incursion mission.   Another major issue is the PvP, dark zone. When the game launched it was really costly to go rouge and a lot of people we just cooperating for the most part. Now all the penalties for going rouge have been nurfed and you’re more likely going to get killed by some random hacker who is running around killing people for kicks because he/she is already maxed gear and does not need to go around and kill you to steel your gear. Ubisoft should have had multiple dark zones like they had shown when they announced this game a few years ago at E3. Different dark zones with varying penalties for encouraging people to be cooperative or not; This would have solved for the most part, the need to adjust the dark zone over and over again. I for one would have like to have multiple dark zones and have all the different bonuses/penalties for going rouge/ cooperative play.  *As of right now after the April 29th 'Ban Hammer' drop, the dark zone as it stands rewards players for being an a**. A PvP zone in which to get the gear you have earned to your inventory you have to call a supply drop. That mechanic is fine, but what isn't is that there are now groups of people just camping drop zones to kill anyone not in their group trying to extract dark zone gear. I have been gaming a very long time and I think this is the first PvP game where I have been actively punished for not being an assh*** in the game. Also why am I getting killed by people with a dark zone rank of 99, my question is why are they in the same dark zone as me, why did Ubisoft not separate people by dark zone rank and gear level and lastly how in the world did you get to dark zone 99 last month with all the rapid hackers in the dark zone without cheating. All these problem for the most part would have been fix if they had multiple dark zones. Also to that end why is it that the people who kill you and steal your stuff don't show up on a play log. The way it is now you can't really review your actions and you can forget about even look up the people that screw you over. Even if it is to see if they were legit screwing you over or using ill-gotten gains to screw you over. If Ubisoft wanted me to tell them if someone is cheating, Ubisoft should have given the average player the tools to look up the assailant at least on a basic level.  Then there is the incursion itself. It was sort of fun, but not. The enemies don’t really use any real tactics except for charge at you gun's blazing. Normal enemies just melt and die from level 30 weapons but the incursion is different and not in a good way. Every enemy now has the HP of a challenge mission boss and can do damage that is comparable to the average level 30 player but the enemy now have an accuracy rating of 100% stacked with a stability rating of 100%.   There are many more glaring issues, but the ones listed above irk me the most. The short end of it is don’t get this game as it is. It is very broken and not worth anyone’s time or money.

This review will be short, as I can't really find much to say about this game other than what has already been said. I am terribly disappointed in this game. I have been looking for an awesome MMO for awhile now, ever since Conan Unchained and Guild Wars, this was far from anything even remotely palate pleasing. So without further bemoaning, but with more to come! here I go:   Character Customization - I haven't played in awhile, but if you're looking for even the most basic of basic customization options we have come to expect from MMOs, you'll be disappointed. Barely any customization can be made in hairstyle, or in appearance, barring minimal facial changes, with minimal variation. You can't change height or weight, either. Most starting characters will look very similar, and the only uniqueness to your character comes from boring looking articles of clothing you find throughout the world. I call them boring because they are drab, and all of them essentially fit into very few stock looks.   Weapons - Yeah, they look nice. That's about all I have to say about them. They have no 'oomph,' and there's not really a feeling of 'wow' or satisfaction when a rare weapon drops. Furthermore, there is no satisfaction to be gained from 'modifying' one's weapons - The suppressor does literally nothing when fighting the AI. You may as well just not use it.   AI - Horrible. You know how the AI in FEAR - a game that came out around a decade ago - reacted somewhat realistically in trying to flank the player and how the soldeirs utilized moderately realistic commands and voice chatter? Yeah, that's not here. The AI may as well be zombies. They run at you like rabies-ridden rejects with no modicum of realism to their behavior patterns. Now, I know, it's an MMO and the AI in MMOs isn't like in FPS game, but this IS a shooting game so I expected something more than just imbecilic....imbeciles..From taking over the same spots as dead guys, to charging like maddened bulls right at you - there is no semblance of realism at all. Moreover, they are generic, boring, bullet sponges. I can't think of a single unique element, or memorable element, among any of the standard enemies, or 'boss' type enemies. A player can empty an entire magazine into one and it'll take away maybe 2/3 of his health. To be blunt, killing the AI is not satisfying, it's boring.  Raids/Dungeons - No. I mean, you can join 'dungeons' with other players but it's just running through a generic building shooting guys. Then you shoot a boss guy. Since there are no defined classes, there's no challenge other than trying to kill the bullet sponges before they kill you. No teamwork is needed.   Audio is passable. A gun sounds like a gun, there are some generic, overused taunts and communications used by the enemies. Nothing immersive, especially when they repeat lines and run out in the open toward you like mindless zombies.   The atmosphere is not at all engulfing. I never once felt like I was actually IN a desolate city - well, I mean...I did feel it was desolate but mostly because the generic NPCs dotting the landscape may as well be cardboard cutouts that float around. They serve no purpose, and add nothing to the game. In fact, their artificiality is more frustrating than there simply being no neutral NPCs at all. There are set zones where there are enemies as well - no roving patrols. I can't think of any element of the world in this game that made me feel immersed.   Community - Anti-social from what I have seen. I can't blame them as there's no reason to socialize with other players, no incentive to band together(in the normal PvE regions, I didn't do Dark Zone stuff because of the claims of hacking and because I don't have anyone to venture to the dark zone with, again, I didn't make any friends here because there was no incentive to band together). In my time playing, the chat was dead, and I saw zero support for something akin to a guild.   Progression - About as dull and lifeless as every other aspect of this game. The player is required to gather certain items to level up portions of his(the gender neutral form of it, so don't be offended SJWs) 'home base.' As that happens, the player can follow a VERY linear progression tree that offers no freedom of choice whatsoever. You will always have the same level of skills as every other person who chooses a, for example, primarily 'healer' archetype - though being a healer is impossible as everyone can heal, and it's not satisfying because, well, no one cares if you heal them as they can heal themselves. You'll notice I said 'archetype' now, and before mentioned there being no defined classes - this is because there ARE 'trees' - if you can call 3 very basic options skill trees - and you can pour points into them...but I haven't seen it really matter across any of the 'classes.' Regardless of which of the bare, basic, trees you go down - you'll be lobbing grenades and spraying marshmallows in a frenzy just like everyone else who went a different path.   The amount of content here is also pitiful. I was bored of 'exploring' the 'open world' within 5 hours. Once you've gotten beyond the initial 'oh, this is kind of cool' factor, you'll be bored of the drab environment that never changes color palate.  Crafting - Pfffftshhh. Bahahahahahaha. Oh dear lord, oh please, don't make me laugh.   To conclude, I strongly advise you to look elsewhere if you want a good MMO with guns. This is far, far from that. Lacking even the basic skeleton of what makes an mmo successful - from a feeling of uniqueness to your character, to a sense of achievement in obtaining new weapons and armor, to any sense of progression. Even if you just want to pop off some zombie-like AI with friends, or try your hand at gunning down the 1337 hackers in the Dark Zone - you can DEFINITELY get that fix from better games. Avoid this one like - well, things that you find highly detestable..like brussel sprouts or something.

I could not, in good conscience, recommend this game to anyone at the moment. The end game is entirely based around a forced PvP area(to acquire crafting materials referred to as division tech) that is plagued with hackers who upon killing you can cost you up to a half hours worth of gameplay in progress(since the PvP area has penalties for death whether or not you have killed another player).    The hackers themselves are not the reason I cannot recommend this game, it is the complete lack of transparency or visible effort by Ubisoft to crack down on the hackers. They are more concerned with punishing individuals who abuse the glitch filled PvE 'raid/horde mode' in a verbal and visible manner, than they are with fixing their forced PvP hack fest. The evidence of this lack of effort to crack down on hackers is evidenced in the sheer prevalence of it. If hacking was being properly tracked and punished, hackers would not be so prominent or easily identifiable in the manner that they currently are.    There are hackers that literally stream and post on youtube that are still playing the game even though they are open and provide evidence themselves that they are hacking. There is no fair play system that provides after startup checking of game files, and while this measure is not a fool-proof prevention method, it is a deterrent and can help track and more readily identify hackers to the game developers.    The companies(Massive and Ubisoft) claim to be banning hackers but if any true form of punishment was being handed out there would not be such an open and blatant disregard for the games ToS.   I thank you for reading this entire post if you have done so, and while the PvE aspect of the game is enjoyable, it is not feasible to play solely in the PvE area and be competitive with individuals that venture into the dark zone. I personally have 600 hours of gameplay invested, and in my personal experience the hacking issues are only getting worse as the game progresses. I encounter 6-7 hackers a day while trying to gain valuable dark zone levels, and in total have lost 367k dark zone experience to these individuals which equates to gaining levels 1-32(roughly) in the dark zone and (based on efficiency in farming DZ experience) roughly 20 hours of gameplay progress.   I urge you to add this game to your wishlist, but abstain from purchasing until the hacking problem has been fixed or they provide a viable end game solution to allow players to be competitive in end game PvE progress without a need to travel into the Dark Zone.   I have endeavored to provide a detailed explanation of why you should abstain from purchase at this time, and I hope that should you buy the game you are not disappointed when your end game DZ time comes and you begin to encounter hackers.

Tom Clancy's: The Division (No Spoilers)  A pretty decent game, to say the least, but also a victim of a number of crippling issues that happen to ruin aspects of the game, most notably anything related to player versus player. Although these issues are far from what they used to be (cheating seems far less common, as I have not run into any recently), many of the existing issues relate to balance and have not been addressed so far.  Overall, I'd recommend this game - the PVE aspect of the game is fun and has been, thus far, time well spent in my opinion, especially with the updates that have rolled out. I do not, however, own the season pass and the DLC that fall under it, so I cannot speak for that content, but I have heard good things about it.  I'm recommending this game, but not at full price. The game should be played in short bursts, in my opinion, especially in the end game as gameplay can be tedious and repetitive (due to the nature of the game). I'll go into my main gripes below.  My main gripes concerning the following:     Time to kill is tiny. Compared to the Beta, which I enjoyed a lot, time to kill is often so quick that an entire squad can be decimated by a single person if they have focused on DPS. Even tank builds (extremely high HP) do not last too long, especially if they have any damage or electronics output (in other words, wish to be able to do anything).    Although not so much as an issue before, weapons like shotguns and LMGs seem far less practical in PVP than what would be expected. Shotguns may be tended to in the future, due to the coming stagger in PVP, but I do not believe shotguns will ever be on par with submachine guns (high DPS, close range and high crit), assault rifles (accurate, fairly high DPS, medium range) or snipers (if set out right, generally instantly gibs targets).    Dark zone, despite efforts made by the developers, is still focused on killing your targets as quickly as possible; at the highest levels, turning their hitpoint bar into a killfeed notifcation takes mere seconds, at most - there is little point in going high health, if you can deal enough damage to negate even the tankiest of tanks. Electronics is a bit of a mixed bag - some of the skills do hurt, but I've found that DPS trumps a large amount of raw damage (for example, a sticky bomb doing 100k+ damage in AOE is nice, as it hurts multiple targets, but 300k+ dps guns generally does better, especially when solo. Electronics with 3 DPS guys does seem to be better than 4 DPS, due to the ability to remotely revive and various buffs.    DLC items are of a static level, and so are not viable outside of the very early game. They are, however, fairly overpowered early on, but quickly become useless. This is specifically talking about packs and guns you get as part of some of the DLC packs - it would have been better if they were cosmetic 'skins' that can be applied to any item, or at least the items their skins are built on top of.    Developers... Lied a lot about of the game? I'm not sure if lied would be the right word, but they certainly were not entirely truthful. I'll explain; what they had shown in the E3 footage was largely pre-rendered and much was not included in the actual game release (I get the graphics downgrade, not abnormal). I'd call it false advertising, but whatever. I got a different game to what I'd seen and I wasn't happy at first, but I've come to like what I got instead. I still think the PVP was best during the beta, however. You can look up ubisoft downgrades video/s - people have done comparisons.   However, as I've gone into some of my gripes, I'll mention some of the stuff I do like.     Weapon selection is great - there is a pretty large selection of primary and secondary weapons, but sadly many of them do not hold up in the min-max environment that is the dark zone. More so when people have fine-tuned their builds over many weeks or months.    Unique PVE factions, and though you might get tired of seeing them over and over again, at least it isn't one faction and they do play differently from each other. They are all tied to the story, so I won't go into them.    Lots of missions to do, both with your friends or on your own. The PVE part of the game can be done solo, if you wish, but it is pretty easy to level ahead of the missions, therefore making them easy. However, many of the post end-game missions (which can be repeated) do not suffer from being too easy, and can be difficult at times, especially on challenging. You may want a friend or three when you hit the end-game.    TL;DR   It is a pretty good RPG casual PVE shooter, all in all, but not so great of a PVP game (looking at you, dark zone) due to balance issues.

Definitely got my money's worth, but sucks to see a game with so much potential squander the gamer base with mediocre mistakes. I understand that it's only been a month, but they've been beta testing for at least 3. And though I will continue to play this game, I simply cannot recommend it at the current state of the game to any new gamers seeking to discover the world that is The Division, as the cons WAY outweigh the pros.   ******* Pros: ******* - Matchmaking is very easy and fast to get a group - Group Missions are very monotonous but if you have a bunch of friends it's fun - Storyline is okay at best - Graphics are pretty good - Immersive Scenery, the scaling and detail to the world are amazing - Graphic Mood, if you actually take a second to look at the world around, it's pretty morbid what's actually happenning. You can tell they're put some serious time into making the world - Dark Zone, regardless of what you hear, is SUPER FUN pvpwise - Squad based gameplay is great, you grab a buddy and you'll have endless hours of fun, that is if you can avoid hackers  ******* Cons: ******* - This game is Hacker central due to ABSOLUTELY NONE anti-cheat detection - To report a hacker is an absolutely ridiculous process that's done manually and very inefficient for all parties involved - I can't play the funnest part of the game (Dark Zone) without having run into a hacker at least once or twice an hour - When they're not cheating in PVP, they're cheating in PvE, instantly clearing new content with the worst gear, it's very demotivating, simply youtube division hacks or cheats to see what I mean - Hacks are ridiculously easy to obtain, pay $15 after googling the division hacks and you're good to go - Glitches are everywhere, such as falling through the floor and getting stuck behind barricades - A lot of exploits, can basically go anywhere on the map and see any content or skip much of the game's instances - Very grindy and is more unforgiving for newer players, especially with the new updates that cater to the older players - Appearance doesn't have much variety, especially with clothing - Best gear in game is craftable, but the RNG to get god tier talents and dmg or armor and certain stats are horribly small percentages. And the means to obtain the materials to craft although isn't incredibly difficult, it's very grindy and time consuming for minimal percent chances to get what you would like - DZ Server sometimes has a delay and lag up to a full second behind  TL;DR Game can be good, grind heavy but good, and hacks are everywhere and are ruining the game.  Potential: 8-9/10 Currently: 3-4/10

This game will never become good because the entire design philosophy behind it is flawed. And I only need to inform you about one aspect of the game which should help you decide not to ever buy this game or any Ubisoft game for that matter.  This game has no end game, no enemy diversity, nothing else than mindlessly grinding bad gear to ultimately get to the good gear which serves no purpose. And the only real incentive there used to be for grinding gear was to become strong in PVP.  But the thing that I want to point out is the bracket system. The implementation of this system has split up the playerbase in brackets based on their gear score. So now everyone is equal and nobody is special. The problem with this is that the players who grind the best gear will also be the loneliest players. And this game already feels bland and empty. You also can't play with your casual friends if your gear score outlevels theirs. So the brackets enforce solo play.  Another problem is that solo players will always be at a disadvantage in the Dark Zone because in order to min-max, they have to cap themselves just underneath the max gear score for their current bracket, This gear score cap prevents players from creating truly powerful characters. This means that you'll always be an average Joe compared to the other people you meet in the Dark Zone, no matter how much time you waste on grinding for gear. It also creates a zone where solo players will almost never be able to beat grouped players, so strength in numbers is pretty much the only way to play it. It also does not help that the bracket system splits up the few that are still left playing, now that over 80% of the playerbase have already quit playing.  But the absolute worst consequence of bracket implementation is that you'll be equal to every player you meet. So when you hit level 30, you will play with and against others who have just turned 30. When you finally get some good gear, you play with and against others of the same gear score. When you finally get that perfect gear drop, you'll just end up being paired with others that have perfect gear drops.  There is just no incentive to ever grind for better gear. And the most enjoyable way to play this game is to stay below level 30 and min-max on the purple gear in the dark zone, even though not many people play in there either.  You have to wonder if you want to buy this game twice. Because this paid DLC-centered game will require you to. And I assure you that the game will never even be worth it's own price once, let alone twice.

Very solid carrot-on-a-stick loot mechanics akin to Diablo and Borderlands packaged in a cover shooter (like Gears of War) playing in the adeptly crafted remnants of New York - that's pretty much Division.   I've took my time getting to current max level 30 (it took me about 50 hours or so, but can be done in 20 as well) and don't have any regrets: while the missions and especially the enemies (there are about 18 or so enemy types in the whole game and only one I'd consider a proper 'Boss') tend to get slightly repetitive, the shooting mechanics, loot system, graphics design and sound design kept me going.  Running through the street canyons of New York at night while lighting scatters through an emerging, dense snow storm and a distant gun fight realistically echoes from the large buildings creates an immersive environment to get lost in: kudos to developer Massive. What helps a lot in these regards is that the game has almost no loading screens. Only during fast travel between safe houses in the PvE world, entering and leaving safe houses in the Dark Zone (large PvE+PvP environment with the hardest mobs and the occassional rogue agent) and for some reason using elevators (really, guys? GUYS?!) you'll see a loading screen - everything else is seemless.  The loot system works reasonably well. If you didn't get a cool drop from an enemy or so, the countless merchants in the game world have an ever rotating arsenal of good stuff to buy with hard earned money (mhhh, SOCOM M1A from a few days ago~). If the merchant can't provide, there's always crafting through blue prints you can either buy or earn through finishing missions. And in case of cases, enter the Dark Zone - risky but often times highly lucrative, it's currently the best way to get to high end loot, which you'll have to extract from it by calling in a helicopter to predefined areas. This will not only cause all nearby mobs to gather at the 'extraction point', but every agent in the Dark Zone will see it as well - latter will come and most likely help, while others just want to watch the world burn. I'm looking at you, you ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who shot me in the face while I tried to extract a pretty nice piece of equip, gaaah.  The loot progression comes to a sudden halt at some point of course - endgame has always been a grind in any game providing it in the last 15 years or so, and Division isn't any different. This can be frustrating, and I hope Massive addresses this issue in due time, but it won't stop me from recommending this game: it's very solid from the get-go and easily provides a proper return of (steep) investment if you like these kind of games.  Servers have been mostly stable, but occassionally hick up - during my about 87 hours of game play, I had to suffer from 2 or 3 disconnects and one downtime.   Bugs are existent in this game and there are currently two (in the widest sense) big ones I know of that can be a deal breaker: 1. Crafted Backpack-Bug that seems to kill peoples' ability to log in 2. Several exploits in the Dark Zone that allow people to drop under the map, teleport around, no need to reload etc.  Other than those - which need to be taken care of properly - I personally only stumbled over the following, minor things. - During a mission, I tried to take cover and clipped into the wall. Game removed me from the mission since it recognized I was out of bounds - UI bug. Values (like DPS, health, etc.) are all over the place depending on what kind of equipment you're hovering with your mouse cursor. Sometimes the values don't update at all when changing equipment until you return to the inventory overview, only to revert to their bugged state when you begin hovering equipment slots again. This should be taken care of, since it can be very irritating, especially for new players.  All in all a very promising game with a steep price tag. Much like Diablo 3 (the epitome of turning a game around), I can see 'The Division' staying in my gaming library for a long time.

If you are a fan of Destiny and other loot based games and shooters you will feel right at home. If you love battle royale type games try out the new Survival gamemode. If you love Diablo then try out the randomly generated underground DLC missions. If you love raids from WoW and Destiny then you will love the incursions and if you love cover based shooters such as Watch_Dogs then you will feel right at home.  The Division has seperated itself from the rest, it has a very intruiging story (not amazingly excecuted in game, but its pretty in depth) that will keep you with the eery feeling in your gut while playing. The map is also very in depth and the Dark Zone is a very cool concept and place to play in.  I wont keep going but you get the idea, its a much better game than it was at release, and it has my tick of approval!

Not worth the price, in my opinion. Not only that, but it crashes way too much for me to consider it enjoyable.   Gameplay is fun for a while, but rather bland. To be fair, it's tough to do things in a way that makes them seem fresh and new when everything in the shooter/MMO world has been done so many times.   On the bright side, it is pretty well polished. The environment is damn nice, it's immersive, the effects are very well done and the changing weather can make playing the same mission completely different a second or third time through. However, I have found myself out of interesting things to do. The encounter missions (what seem to be random NPC events where you can jump in and help the JTF [good guys] fend off some rioters or escaped convicts) get pretty stale sooner rather than later. You're either freeing hostages, stopping an arms deal, defending a patrol from getting lambasted by rioters, or the really lame scavenger hunt encounters where you have to slowly lug what looks like a suitcase full of supplies back to a container because the JTF are too ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ lazy to walk 50 feet and get it themselves. Missions are pretty cool for a while, but I never did a mission that stood out to me as an epic experience. It's just (1. Take cover and shoot at bad guys (2. Listen to radio instructions/chatter and advance to the next area (3. Rinse and repeat.  As of May 3rd, 2016 when writing this review, this is an overpriced CTD simulator. I really don't know why it's been crashing so much lately, because it did work very well a few months ago. I've been running it on a 5930K @4.4Ghz with 64GB of DDR4 @2800Mhz and a 980ti @1360Mhz. Disappointingly I only get around 45 FPS at 2K when the shooting starts. That is only when it runs, though. As of now, it loads up and crashes on start. I've done some troubleshooting, but it's kind of a sense of 'I paid $60 for this game, and run it on high end hardware; It should  just work ' that makes me want to just forget about it.  If you're into MMO's, and you want something that's modern day and well done graphically and mechanically, it's a good pick for around $25, no more than $30. And really, it may get better. The updates that roll out do seem to address issues, and they seem to have an intention of making it run right. The only issue I have with that is that it's not Early Access, it's gold release and you're charging a premium price for something that really doesn't work all that great and feels lacking in content. They did add some more missions in the last update, so don't discredit too much on that, but I really don't know what they added since when I went to check it out I crashed to the desktop as soon as the world loaded.  A negative part of those updates, however, is that they seem to be nerfing things to balance the game towards people who are just going to grind. You used to be able to get way better gear faster with loot and by combining lower grade components to make higher grade components needed to craft better gear. That just got seriously nerfed to the point that it's not really a viable option anymore. Don't get me wrong, the good stuff is there and it's obviously made so you don't max out too fast, but it feels like there are too few missions to necessitate the grinding required to get supreme weapons.   TL:DR Not worth $60 because: Graphics great but poorly optimized Lacking content Grinding required, repetition to be expected. Crashes to desktop. All the damn time.

I have spend 225 hours in the game so far.  And for the most part i did enjoy it greatly. But i slowly start to dislike more and more mechanics they introduce.  But let's first go over the good sides.  The Gunplay feels great. Even if you can't stand that enemies have such a large lifepool the guns respond in a way that makes it enjoyable to shoot.   The Coversystem feels great as well and i do enjoy to use it as much as possible.   I loved everything about this game until i hit level 30, what was after 20~ish hours in. After that i tryed the challenge mode the first time, with my purple and blue gear and of course we got utterly destroyed.  But we had something to work towards so overall that was still a really nice experience. The joy we felt for beating a challenging mission the first time without dying was just great.   And that was also the point where everything went down in a spiral of bad choices. At least that's how it felt to me. I had to bring up my DZ rank for some of the cool blueprints so we started doing this. Picked up some +exp gear and started farming. But we met a lot of Rouge agents so out farming routine was not as efficient as i expected it to be.  Don't get me wrong here i love the PvP in this game. But if i intend to FARM i wanna farm and not be forced into PvP.  This was the first problem i encountert that really annoyed me. As we kept farming it was more and more clear that the Darkzone is not that enjoyable as i thought it might be.   I do enjoy the PvP but to be forced into PvP while i want to farm is just a pain. It does not give me enjoyment at all. Once i reached the rank i was aiming for (50 at that time) i bought what i wanted to buy and started crafting. I did get pretty much everything i wanted and we enjoyed farming Challenges and other stuff preparing for the first Incursion as it should be released soonish.   Finally that day came and surprisingly i was able to play on patchday. So good job there. Just to realize how bad the first Incursion was. I did expect to have an actuall Mission where we need to work together as a team to clear different stages.  While it was hard i didn't really feel that much enjoyment out of it. The mechanics seemed meaningless because all we had to do was turtle for a couple of waves until a bomb spawned then kill the guy with the bomb and place it on the APC while deactivating the turrets.  Okay, sure. The second time we tryed we managed to finish the mission. Everyone was happy and since we did have pretty good highend Gear and were confident in our ability we thought we just try it on Challenging right after that.  Even our 'tank' with 120.000 life and capped armor got one shotted.  So, what's the point on being tanky? we droped all the life stuff and went full DPS which helped a great deal.  But in the end we just 'died' through the mission while running away. This was the least enjoyable thing i have ever done in The Division. Even in comparisson to the Darkzone where all we did was run a big circle route between bossmobs. For HOURS!  And those not feel good to get oneshotted from pretty much everything and i feel like this is a really 'bad' way to make a mission difficult.   Some days later i saw a new incursion on the north side of the map with a recommended GS of 220 for HARD! So, all the gear i farm now will be useless in a month?   If that is the case, is it even worth struggling through all of that not enjoyable content? I did not feel that way. And that kinda makes me sad because i really did enjoy the Division to a great deal. And i sure hope future Patches will fix that problem.  But to get oneshotted in a 'Tactical Shooter RPG' feels just wrong on every level. If i want to play a rougelike game i'd buy one.    So if you are looking for a game that will give you a geat experience for leveling up and starting out with challenging missions. Go for it. But if you are looking for a game with a somewhat decent Endgame and fair gamemechanics i'd stay a way and look how it turns out after a couple of patches.   And i did not even go into Glitches or Hackers since i hope this will be sorted out in time.   There are easy ways to fix a lot of these problems. Take away the oneshot kills and make it difficult through mechanics.   Implement Arenas. The Darkzone just feels like a sad excuse for an PvP Area.  Sure, Manhunt can be fun. Don't get me wrong. But wouldn't it be even more fun in an area where everyone wants to PvP?  I will hit the 'no' button for recommendation here not because i think the game is bad but because i think the game could be so much more!  Edit:   I checked the game out again, not as much but stll to get a feeling for all the new stuff. The game is a lot better.  There are still some problems i really dislike, but i feel like if you can grab it for a decent price, it will entertaine you quite a bit.  I am glad to see that they didn't give up on this game.  While i can recommend it now, you should keep in my mind that this game is only a Looter. All you do is to get loot and nothing else. There is now real tactic involved in battles since you can become so strong that you pretty much can Solo all the important stuff.   So if you enjoy a not to complexe but with decent content looter, this might be something for you.  It is pretty much a Action RPG in third person. :3 if that sounds like something you'd enjoy, go for it.

This isn't a review of The Division game as a whole, which is a good game, so much as it is a review of the Survival DLC.   Is it worth it? Yes, without a doubt! The Survival DLC is easily the most fun I've had in a game for quite some time. Since its release I've played over 140 hours in total and almost all of it in Survival PVE mode. It is a challenging mode where you compete over scattered resources in the city, and trying not to get killed by progressivly harder enemies roaming the streets because you start out with just a sidearm, and at the same time battling the weather which also will kill you, and last but not least...You are infected and you have only 1 hour real time left to hit the streets looking for resources while the game costantly reminds you that the clock is ticking. Every time I go in something is different, such as your initial starting point, your fellow survivors and how good they are at getting to the best loot before I do. Weather condition so bad you can't really be sure you aren't running into 6 elite hostiles next time you go around a corner. If you are lucky you find a lone survivor like yourself and together you battle it out with the end game enemies, the Hunters, and leave the city with your sweet sweet loot. The payday for a successful run is phenomenal. High end gear and weapon you can keep or sell for credits. When I first bought this game I struggled to get 10k credits because you constanly have to upgrade your gear, but with just a few games of Survival 'im in the millions. I only speak from a small amount of time, but I played the closed and open beta, and I followed the game a bit before and after release.   The gameplay is very enjoyable, as long as you understand that you are playing a MMO-esque RPG, not just an FPS/TPS. While FPS/TPS mechanics apply to the game, it has a lot of MMO features and mechanics on top of its shooter facade.   The DLC may not be required, but the Survival DLC is truly worth the money. If you decide to purchase the Season Pass, keep in mind it covers 1 more DLC before the year 2 pass rolls in.   As for player count, it peaks at 40,000 on weekends and averages 16,000 players every day, at least when I'm on and check.   The game is not nearly as much of a grind as some other grindy games, but it does exist during levelling as 'encounters' which are mini-missions which follow a set couple of objectives in different areas. Then, you have your side-missions which are more structured than an encounter, but usually have more straight-forward goals without major surprises. Finally, you have your big main missions, which have some lore to go with the mission story, unique and interesting locations, and usually culminate with a boss fight, such as Joe Ferro or Lae Berrett, or whatever her name is.   As for the world, a lot of it is streets and alleyways, but there are enough things going on to keep it from feeling like empty space. The world is peppered with a decent amount of the previously-mentioned encounters, so the world has stuff to do. The world also has various landmarks and unique locations, but are usually used for missions.   The Dark Zone will either be a turn-off or an attractor, depending on friends and what PVP you like. Essentially, you have a section of the map locked off in a red area, which is open for other players to be in. You fight stronger enemies there with good loot, but the loot must first be extracted to be usable, and can be dropped if you die. The factor other players have in this area is that they can kill you, obviously. Going in with friends is recommended, and is usually pretty fun. Solo players will come to hate the area though, due to 4-man gank squads mowing you down.   The alternative to Dark Zone is the 2nd DLC, Survival. It can be played in PVE, but other players can still finish you off to take your loot. Regardless, Survival uses unique mechanics seperate from the main game, like hunger/thirst, temperature, and an infection timer. The goal is to gear up while maintaining your bodily functions, find virals of the green poison, find some loot in the Dark Zone, and then extract. It feels like a fleshed-out minigame mode that generates serious tension during fights, as your life really matters in the mode. This mode will take some time dedication, anywhere from 30 minutes to 2 hours, but can be played right after you reach the Terminal, so you could play as a level 4 with gear score 256 players and be on even footing.   Overall, The Division is worth a go in its current state, has constant and active support, with plans for more support for at minimum another year, a healthy playerbase, well-rounded activities, 2 flavors of PVP, and a generally fun Singleplayer/Co-op levelling experience. I'd recommend purchasing the DLC/Season Pass/Gold Edition only if they're on sale, but the base game is ok at $60.
