Was very skeptical of the game when it launched and avoided it. I had been hearing some good things about it lately so decided to grab it on the holiday sale - I am so glad I did, the game is fantastic! I am not sure how the game played earlier this year, but my experience the past few days is super positive and I've been having a blast.   Things I like:  - The cliche story. It's done well and there is a lot of atmosphere and little details crafted into the world. - The gun play. This is definitely a cover shooter and the running and gunning feels great and satisfying. - The controls. I have played with XB1 controller and keyboard and mouse. They both feel and play great. - The graphics. Textures look good and the lighting and particle effects are beautiful. - The audio. Ambient sound and music are well done. Gun sounds are pleasing to the ear. - The loot. Love the loot. Guns, mods, armor, clothing... lots of opportunity for customization here.  - The Darkzone. Upon reaching level 10 you gain access to the Darkzone. The city is instanced for you and/or your friends where you won't run into other players unless you head to a hub or a safe house. The Darkzone, however, is openworld and considered a pvp area. This is the most lawless and contaminated area of the city, where any thing goes. I don't recommend running around here solo - the mobs are large and tough, and of course, the threat of other players. The nice thing is the game really encourages socialization and team work when you enter. Voice chat is enabled by default and if you have a mic you can just start talking to people near you and they can hear you without doing anything extra. This makes it really easy to team up with others and communicate effectively. Upon entering the DZ for my first time I immediately encountered 2 other players and helped them finish off a mob, we chatted afterwards and they invited me to their group. The loot in the DZ is awesome, the catch is you can only cary so much of it (I could only cary 6 pieces of loot, I am not sure if you can increase this). Once you get your limit, you can either fight your way out of the DZ, or find an extraction point. Extraction points are areas where you can call in a chopper to extract your hard earned loot (it goes into your stash). Once you signal the chopper, it takes time to show up, during this time NPC mobs will attack. Once the chopper is there, you can load up your loot, and again you will have to defend the chopper for a time limit before it leaves. The system is pretty cool and keeps you on your toes. I loved my time in the Darkzone and can't wait to go back!  Things that could be improved:  - Character creation. There really isn't a lot of ways to customize your character when you create him/her. This didn't bother me too much though, as once you start playing there are tons of ways to customize with gear.  Things I didn't like:  - I haven't ran into any yet.  Summary (TLDR):  A fantastic 3rd person shooter/action game with great graphics, a fun and interesting world, a brutally fun and anxiety inducing multiplayer zone (The Darkzone), and awesome loot!  The most fun I've had in a multiplayer shooter in a few years.

When it came out i only heard bad things about this game, i played it on a free weekend deal, didn´t liked the gameplay at first, because i was playing it like a regular fps, but then i started playing it like you would Assassin´s Creed, being stealthy, using the environment, and getting better weapons by scavenging, directly by finding them, or indirectly by selling enough crap until i could buy something decent.  It´s a great game, very realistic New York, weapons are very fun to mod, gear it´s very well leveled, outfits can be adequated to your liking, somethings you buy somethings you find, the Dark Zone is your best shot to finding good gear and good weapons, also you find the parts to craft the high end weapons of the game, and the chance of loosing your loot is pretty high, but don´t worry about your current inventory, if you die you don´t lose it, you only loose the loot you´ve collected.  The story it´s actually believable, everything that happend until this point in the game (haven´t finished it yet) it´s credible, and that makes a good story, the way that people act it´s pretty damn accurate and if you´ve got the hero complex you´ll love to put some bullets on those who prey on the weak and helpless.  Let me be very clear, if you wanna go Rambo on everything spraying bullets everywhere go play something else, this game is for smart people who like using other skills in adition to their gun skills, the game doesn´t really have a tutorial and you´ll have to develop tactics and figure out how somethings work, especially if you don´t read tips when the game starts loading.  It´s not the best game you´ll ever buy, but it´s a lot of fun, especially if you like the Ubisoft type of game. Since the patches, it's considerably less 'grindy', easier to get high GS gear/guns (without the need to enter the dreaded Dark Zone), and an overall more enjoyable experience as it feels more like a shooter now than a bullet sponge simulator. I especially like the inclusion of the 'World Tiers' so all players can choose the difficulty level at which they want to play, catering to casual and more dedicated players alike.  While I never personally had any specific gripes with The Division prior to 1.4/1.5, I can however see what people were upset about previously, but at this point I feel the majority of those issues have been addressed and resolved as the dev team really took to heart player feedback and they committed to tailoring the Division to suit it's player base. As such I can fully recommend this game to anyone looking to take the leap.

This game has absolutely nothing to do with 'Tom Clancy's' style of games and even as a stand-alone cover-based third-person looter-shooter co-op open world game it isn't very good... But it isn't particularly bad either. The story, Bullet sponge opponents and few technical issues clearly drag this down. The Division is visually a good looking game and it does sounds great. And it might be fun when played with a group of friends of equal level. I'd give it 'yellow' recommendation but Steam only has 'green' and 'red' and this is a Ubisoft title with Uplay on it so I'm leaning towards the 'red' i.e. I'm not recommending this.  There are few design decisions which I'd like to talk about like how the cover-to-cover actions work and you can still take bullets while you're in the cover to name some. I think it's a bug since there clearly was few occasions when I was against a wall and the AI opponent was able to shoot me through the solid wall. However going through all these issues would take a long time to go through and I'm not sure it's worth it. So I'm just going to say that there are things that some people probably will dislike greatly. Opponents in this game have clear issues with their AI as well.  Also the looting aspect in the Division is practically every Ubisoft open world loot-game ever and that ♥♥♥♥ is so old that I cannot find the fun from it any longer. And I hate it when I die and have to run 5-10 minutes back to action and then almost immediately die again and repeat this few times. It's being made worse that you'll see a loading screen everytime you die and the game reverts to earlier save point. You'll also lose whatever mission progress you had after last checkpoint which is pretty ok actually since death will have some weight to it.  Playing The Division with random people is pure hell because the game will adjust difficulty based on group stats and if there are high level(s) then all low levels essentially drag the team down. Also I met during this weekend quite a bit of Division players who were just total jerks.  The story isn't particularly well written as it starts from nowhere, goes nowhere and (apparently also) ends nowhere. I don't get why does every character in this game have an attitude problem towards everything. They're in such an emergency situation doing ridiculous actions and having such expressions and thoughts that I don't find the characters relatable at all.  I'd like to put also emphasis on how they aren't 'Tom Clancy'-type characters whom would lean towards how actual military & government official -background personel would behave and act. I can say that with fair certainty as a guy who actually reads Clancy's books. In any case there has been a steady decline towards your regular 'action heroes'-type thing in 'Tom Clancy's' branded games. I'd like to Red Storm just return to doing what they did in 90s.  Visually the Division is great. It looks great and has stable framerate and is a pretty smooth game. However I'd strongly recommend that people disable BS effects like chromatic aberration that ruin the screen image quality. Also the forced screenshaking is quite annoying.  Music and sound in this game is quite good and suits the theme of the game well. However as part of the issues with the characters the voice acting is just ridiculous at times.  Physics have some issues in this game but nothing too crazy.  Controls work great in the Division and there isn't really anything to complain about. They even offer dual bindable sockets for keyboard and mouse players which is just great. Massive Entertainment knows their stuff.  This is a game that is sold at Steam but it absolutely requires installing of Ubisoft's Uplay. It takes a long time to download and install and it essentially used so that Steam is merely used to chainload and then launch Uplay title. That's just cancer. This game also doesn't really have a real offline single-player since you need to (according to my understanding) be constantly connected to the servers. If you stop playing you'll be disconnected from the servers after a moment and thrown into main menu which I thought was annoying. The Division also has microtransaction as part of the game.  I still have the absolutely grinch Ubisoft scripted showcase in my mind which was just about the most unrealistic showcase of team-based multiplayer voice chat conversation I've heard.  The Division also has subtitles for many languages including Finnish language which I found to be a great addon even thought it has few translation issues and the in-game menu's are not available in Finnish.  I see here absolutely loads of wasted potential in the Division. It could have been great but they've dropped the ball with it. I played this few hours and reached level 15 as a part of the free weekend promotion they had so I've marked it as such.  I'm trying to like the Division really really hard but I just don't like it. And because of multiple issues I experience with it it I cannot recommend it to people.

Heya!  Well lets start with the good sides of the whole thing, shall we?   First of all the game looks AWESOME! The visuals are amazingly done and give this apocalyptic feel. This is especialy true for the Dark zone. They got the whole apocalyptic setting better than anything I have seen so far. Sounds are also nicely implemented. And I mean everything from weapon sounds to ambient sounds of distant battles! As for the story side they could have done more with it but, hey, I did not buy this cause of story tellin.  Thats about it.  From there it goes only downhill! Content that comes with the game is REALY short. You could reach end game in not more than 2 days of casual gameplay. That would not be such a bad thing if only PvP thing worked as it´s supposed to. But I will come back to that matter later on. As I already said the game has very nice visuals which took, IMHO, 80% of invested development time. Once you finnish off the main story 3/4 of this beautiful world stands empty and useless since you dont have any reason at all to ever go back there. They do try to force you to revisit some locations to collect some resources sometimes but other than that there is nothing. It´s almost as if they just gave up on the whole game after they did the bloody map!   And missions? Aside from main story missions (15 or so...) there are some side quests and encounters. Both are basicaly the same 4 missions repeating all over the map. Those include repairing some radio towers, freeing hostages, killing some mini bosses for example. And not to forget my favorite: Virus research encounters! OH those are... fun! You basicaly run through a building turning on some box looking things... hope you like them cause you will be doing them over and over again since they are required to research all your abilities. Thanks for that Ubisoft!  Also main story missions are buged and sometimes, after this loooooooong loading screen you will end up infont of a mission which can´t be started. I´ve heard roumors that there is this special technique to start the missions when they are buged. But I never managed to do it other than disbanding the crew (after finaly finding a english speaking crew with headsets! Rare commodity...) and starting over. Plus why would I even have to know that??? FIX IT UBI!  But what happenes in that 1/4 of this so called open world? Thats where the Dark zone is! I gotta say I was realy excited by the promises this game gave regarding the gameplay in the Dark zone. They failed EPICALY! As you will find out once you get in there match making in the Dark zone is not related to your gear rank, or your dark zone level. The thing that determines with whom you will be playing is your PvE level. And since everyone reaches 30... you get the picture. The thing is that you as a fresh rank 30 will be hunted and killed by players against you will have absolutely no defences. They will have better gear and work in teams and shoot you just for being there. Do not get me wrong I´m all for PvP but this has nothing to do with skill or fairplay if a player has absolutely no chance of defending himself. Then there are hacks that exploit non existant security measures of this game. Players with 16k RPM, no recoil, autoaim, teleport hack tools are roaming the streets and can basicaly kill you from a mile away before you even see them. If it was just for the the fact that you died and respawned it would not matter so much but you will loose your loot, xp and some other things every time you die. And Ubisoft is NOT doing anything about it. They talk about it but so far they ahve not moved a finger to fix anything.   What they did do is add one free 'incursion' so far. That is a good thing, right? Wrong! First of that is NOT a raid like mission. It is basicaly one big room with some cover filled with lots of already existing enemies. It is hard I have to admit but that is not what I consider a raid. What it does offer is access to some new high end gear sets. Those give out some pretty awesome bonuses, which brings us to another problem. Like the rest of the game the incursion is glitched. There is a posibility of going out of the map and doing it from the safe distance. Ofc that players found that out nearly instantly and spamed that mission (it´s a bloody mission, it´s not a raid!!!) on chalenging difficulty and got some pretty amazing gear. And that brings us back to the flood of gear score 215+ players in the Dark zone who will be more than happy to shoot your puny character down. Once again Ubisoft is not doing anything about it since the glitch is still available for abuse.   Finaly, we come (back) to the topic of a player base this game has. Such a gathering I have rarely seen in any game. Aside from aforementioned hack and glitch abusers there are various other... individuals... that will make your life beautiful! For instance more than half of player base does not know the purpose of a push-to-talk settings for example. The other day a guy was eating chips right into the ear of entire team. Ofc you can mute them but on higher difficulties being able to communicate is a MUST. That being said I know this is not Ubis fault. But, please, could you not make dedicated servers just for russians and french at least??? XD There are decent guys there with whom I had fun doing runs but they are rare and far inbetween. Oh, and good luck trying to find a random group for Incursion on chalenging difficulty!   So, after a lot of time invested in this game I have to say that this game is a half finished product spit out too early for waaaaaaay to much money! Stear clear of it until it improves in major ways.   And thats not likely to happen cause they already got their milions out of it. Remember: Ubisoft = Watchdogs, Farcry 4 (mod for FC3), Far cry primal (mod for a mod for FC3)...   There...  I just hope you didn´t buy it already!  EDIT: after all this time it still sucks in the same way. And yet some play it still! -.-

For reference I played during the Free Weekend, hence 'recieving the product for free'  This game sucks. Plain and simple, it offers the player nothing more than what feels like radiant quests. Now, there are a few things I like about it and I'm sure it's much more enjoyable with friends, but the game in general is mediocre in terms of gameplay, story, voice acting (You'd think the post-apocalypse would feature a bit more cussing that the occasional 'damn' and the rare 'b!tch,' no?), and gunplay.  Gameplay, from the first 6 or so levels of play, was just running around New York completing quests that 'help the people, because they really need it!' as the whiny, pre-pubescent-sounding radio operator would have you know. It's kind of like if Dying Light were in third person, didn't have melee weapons, and didn't have free-running.   Story is thrown in there because it was necessary. Black friday, contagious disease planted in New York, special operatives have fancy watches that tell them it's time to become military trained fighters. Because keeping the peace automatically involves using a military force to kill all of the thousands of people that suddenly became super hostile and formed hierarchies in raider groups overnight. After nearly 30 hours of gameplay I feel that I'm sufficiently versed in the game to appraise it. Originally when I was playing the beta and then playing this on release I was quite entertained with it. Now twenty something hours later I still have exactly the same appreciation for it. It really is a good game and that's saying something coming from Ubisoft.   The PVE experience has an engaging storyline, and really solid game mechanics. Don't buy it expecting some kind of combat simulator, this is a RPG shooter first and foremost. That means if you are a lower level than your opponents you are going to be emptying clip after clip into them a la Borderlands style. Even when you are sufficently powerful enough to engage certain enemies, some of them will simply be of a higher standard and some will be bosses. That means extended gunfights where your tactics and use of your abilities will make the difference.   For a new release this game is very polished, performance is great, and no major bugs (although you may run into some minor ones that get patched out frequently.) I run the game on a 2560x1080 monitor with all settings maxed out on my GTX 970 and it really couldn't be any smoother for me, maxing out the Vsync framerates. The graphics and the environment are complicated and detailed and sure look pretty especially with changing times of the day and shifting weather effects.   I've played a fair bit of Destiny and I found it a bit meh, but as there aren't really many team rpg shooter games like that I stuck with it. Now I can confidentally say that there is no reason for me to ever fire up Xbone to play Destiny again. This game far exceeds it in nearly all categories.   Solo play is quite feasible in this game even though it is touted as a team based online game in the same way that the Borderlands series is always still soloable. There's plenty to do in the PVE areas, nothing that REALLY requires a team to accomplish so long as you are sufficiently levelled and are using the right skills and gear. Most of my time in game has been spent solo either in the PVE areas or in the PVP Dark Zones. That being said, grouping up brings you to another level of entertainment. If you don't know anyone that plays it, the matchmaking feature in game couldn't be simpler. Whether you are in PVE or in the Dark Zone its a simple matter of pressing a key in the map or at a matchmaking terminal and suddenly you have your group ready to go. You can also do one on one invites if you see someone in a safe house or in the dark zone that perhaps you don't want to turn your back on without them being in your group.   Pros: - Polished Game - Very solid and unique gameplay - Pretty environments - Character and loot progression - Crafting - Engaging Tom Clancy storyline - Soloable - Fantastic team fun - PVP zone is unique and tense whilst still being very rewarding - Devs look to the future and will be expanding the game further and further as time goes on  Cons - Fairly generic ambient civilians - Limited enemy types (around 4 major enemy factions each with about 4 different types of soldier plus bosses) - some minor bugs   This is probably the first game where I've dismissed the negative criticism it gets on the forums and reviews and I'm glad I did. The trolls are out in force trying (and overall failing) to bring the game down. My advice is to watch a Twitch stream and make up your own mind. That being said, it's the kind of game that is actually a lot more fun to play than to watch so keep that in mind. If you like the combat mechanics and you have a soft spot for looting games like Borderlands or Diablo then you need this game. You won't be disappointed.

Alright so, as of posting this I'm level 28, still got a bunch of PVE stuff to do and way more dark zone to explore, but I see a lot of negative reviews and I think I know what the issue is for real.  This game, as of writing this review, is getting kind of a bad rap. Mostly because hackers were previously running rampant in the dark zone (which is a pvp area), and as it does in any online pvp, it was souring player experience. Recently they've begun to take measures against skilless losers, so that's good.  I think there are two main issues here:  1. People grab The Division expecting it to be a total PVP focused game, and as some of you may know, any developer who releases a game with even a small amount of promises for PVP usually attracts some of the less desirable players, i.e. trolls, hackers, nolifers and so on.  2. The game really doesn't have a ton of content, and while that can be pretty daunting for a 60 dollar purchase, I'm reminded of other early MMOs, countless persistant online worlds who all suffered from the exact same problem. Some of these games sink, some of them swim. For The Division, only time will tell.  To go further into issue one and two at the same time, The Division, in my own opinion and experience, is not a PVP focused game. That may seem strange, as it is absolutely a 3rd person shooter, but I feel like Division was meant to tell a constant story. This is also evidenced by the fact that the upcoming DLC is a rogue-like survival expansion, and I admit, I'm sort of excited to see this come to the game.  I don't think a shooter, or even a Tom Clancy game, absolutely has to be all about PVP. PVP is fun, mind you, but it's nice to have other things to do. That of which do exist in The Division, such as:     Missions (all of which tell a story)    Base upgrading (also part of the story, and for me, a fun thing to participate in)    Crafting (I like my crafting)    Multiple types of item collection/rewards (Being sort of compulsive, I'm a bit drawn to picking up random things, and finding everything)    Gear grinding (This is standard in any persistant online world and/or MMO and I don't see how anyone could feel  that ♥♥♥♥♥♥  about it)    Weapon customization (Love customizing weapons)    The PVP dark zone (An extremely dangerous area with high risk and sometimes good reward)    Matchmaking/group finding (I've found many random groups and had quite a bit fun in that area)    Incursions (A max level sort of thing built for 4 players, like a hardmode dungeon with gear rewards)   And that's pretty much the game right now. Notice that PVP is absolutely not the main focus here, even though it's totally welcome, don't get me wrong. Is it fun? Yes, it totally is. Does it get boring at times? For what it is, and the current state of the game, yeah, it does. I don't think this is a title you're currently meant to play 8 hours straight without pause, though, and I think that's part of the negativity as well. Aside from that, it's perfectly fine in moderated stints, at least if you're like me and have a ton of other things going on outside of game worlds.  Would I recommend it? Despite a lot of the playerbase jumping ship at the first sign of hackers in the DZ, I would, yeah. Even if endgame grinding and risky as hell PVP isn't your thing, there's still about 40 hours of content to have fun with until then, and for me, 40 hours of content alone is getting what you paid for. I know games that take less time to play to an artificial sort of completion and have even less content and fun to be had.  Take all that how you will though, it's just what I think.

(Updated) This is the first time I've ever felt the urge to write a review and I'll start off by saying THIS GAME ISN'T FOR EVERYONE but if you give it a chance and view it with an open mind for the type of game it is, it can be an enjoyable experience. I've read through a large number of reviews, both positive and negative, and I was overwhelmed by the amount of negativity and misinformation people had to say about this game... I'll attempt to break down my experiences with the game so far and give you my take on some negatives people are trying to claim for this game.  1. Launch Day Woes and Server Stability: Although I'm sure people had different experiences, I only experienced a server crash once at the NA launch time, which lasted roughly an hour before Ubi had everything up and running again and I've had zero issues with server stability since. During the crash I kept updated via the vast amount of people streaming the game on Twitch and social media and the majority seemed to be able to reconnect around the same time frame when servers went back up. This didn't sway my initial impression of the game as it seems to be an unfortunate reality that these things happen with almost every major mmo title at launch. If anything, I was actually impressed with how quickly Ubisoft was able to regain server stability and make the game playable for everyone.   2. Game Play and Bullet Sponge: This seems to be a popular bit of criticism and although it's subjective in nature, I feel like the negative comments are from people who simply don't/won't take the time to understand the mechanics this game has set in place. First and foremost this game has many different mechanisms from different genre's meshing together. It's important to understand the core mechanics behind the intended game play. This game is an rpg first and shooter second. They are two very different styles of play. Normal enemies die very quickly if you're loot is up to par with the level content. As for elites taking several clips to kill - well I can't imagine a boss fight, (or an encounter that is meant to be challenging), being enjoyable when an elite mob/boss takes a few extra shots to take down then you pack your ♥♥♥♥ and call it a day. I'll get more in-depth on this in topic 3 but to sum it all up the game plays like an rpg with some minor mmo elements. Your core damage comes from basic attacks (aka shooting) while utilizing positioning, cover, weapon loadout and skills/abilities you have spec'd into with your character. Some claim it to be boring, I find it enjoyable. To each their own.  3. Group Encounters and Dungeons/Main Missions: The way the group encounters are now is a welcome change in my mind. Coming from an mmo background where group content didn't feel all that difficult, I've run several hard mode missions using the matchmaking system in this game and found the encounters depend on much more coordination from your squad using skill separation, target focus and movement/cover swapping during combat. Anyone charging in, running and gunning, expecting to down multiple elites dies very quickly and puts the squad in a tougher spot as you loose vital dps and aggro spread. I've witnessed multiple people try this approach putting themselves in a position where the group can't revive them without dieing themselves. The key is to coordinate priority targets first, ranging from mobs that rush you with melee weapons/shotgun, throw nades, snipe you from afar (they do a ton of damage).. etc and move as a group to regain better cover. There is some fair criticism to be said towards boss mechanics as they do seem to be very repetitive. I'm level 15 now (cap is 30) and haven't really experienced any different mechanics for boss fights. The missions and encounters themselves are different but the boss fight mechanics are relatively the same. Take cover, shoot boss, move to different cover to regain position advantage, rinse/repeat. Certain bosses hold canisters which you can shoot at to explode and do burst damage but all-in-all it doesn't feel all that different from shooting the boss themselves.  4. Loot and Character Progression/Grinding: This is one aspect the game does very well. As many others have said, I have to agree that the game gives off a Diabloesque vibe, leaving you wanting to continually get stronger and progress your character through the game. Obtaining stronger and cool looking loot while increasing your characters stats is definitely a focus in this game which makes it the bread and butter so far for me. I very much enjoy loot based progression and this game does that well enough to keep me wanting more. Combined with the third person shooting, weapon modding and an interesting atmosphere to explore, progression is both addicting and fun, making it feel like less of a grind and more of just playing the game.   So if you manged to come this far, you can probably tell by now my initial impressions of the game are good. I still have some concerns regarding endgame and longevity. I also hope to see more interesting mechanics for boss fights either in the next 15 levels or when challenge mode begins and I start the endgame climb. However, I must say this game is one of the few in years where I feel compelled to play consistently and very much look forward to progressing through the rest of the game. If you're still unsure of whether or not you want to invest, I would suggest doing some research, understand just what type of game this is and see if it appeals to you. If the answer is yes then I would highly recommend it!!  -------------Quick Update---------------  After progressing through more content (level 21 now) I've found boss fights still to feel repetitive from mission to mission. This hasn't pushed me away from the game, as I did some of my own research and understand fights become much more diverse near level cap, but I felt it was a fair bit of criticism to update. One major gripe I have as well is the recycled mini-objectives for wing specific points. I like how they've spread objectives across the map in each zone, leaving you the option to explore and complete them, but one thing that really erked me was how many of the objectives were simply copied and rendered within a different setting of the zone you're in. This is something I feel they could have made more diverse. I don't mind repetition every once and a while but seeing the same thing over and over from zone to zone gets to be a bit much. Thankfully the content in mini-missions and main-missions still feel to have variety, making them feel interesting and giving me incentive to complete them. I'm still looking forward to reaching endgame and doing challenge mode missions as others have described them as 'brutally hard and really enjoyable.' I noticed almost a 50% split in votes and I would love to hear some comments/opinions from others about the game and/or my take so far. See you at level 30!!

I came to the division from destiny. Everyone was super hyped because they were going to do a Destiny style game, but do it right. I was really excited too, but it didnt meet my expectations. I was hoping for a game to replace Destiny, but i was mistaken. The division does some things really well, and some things not so well. Lets start out with the bad and get that out of the way.  The things I didn't like about the DIvision: There is way to much pve, and not enough pvp. There are two ranking systems in the game, one for the pve area, and one for the pvp area. In order to get the best gear you need to rank up in both of the areas. I was happy grinding out levels against pve enemies for a good while, but once I hit rank 30 (maximum pve rank) I was done. I wanted to move on to the pvp and rank up there to get more gear. But the thing is, you can't really level up just by pvping. The darkzone is an area where you rank up from killing pve enemies as well, except the enemies are stronger, and you lose part of your rank if you die. Really disheartening when I reach a new rank, die, then derank. Also, other players can kill you, and take your money and gear you have. thats extremely disheartening also. It makes it almost impossible to do anything in the darkzone without a team running with you.   Now on to the good stuff: The Division had a decent story to it, nothing specail. It wasn't as good as The Last of Us, or as bad as the Black Ops 3 campaign, but somewhere in between. the voice acting and character development was good, I knew exactly who the important people were and what they do. That's something I don't usually see. I liked that. The cover to cover movement felt amazing, I was always in control. The guns all felt unique, and I really had to think about what kind of weapons I wanted to roll with.  I would say that the game is worth the 60 dollars, but only if you enjoy killing the same enemies over and over. If you like playing against other players, this is not the game for you.

The best part of The Division might actually be its UI. It's been a while since I've seen an user interface this slick - The diegetic panels hanging in thin air sell the feeling of modern urban warfare more convincingly than a dozen of imaginary gadgets and beam weapons ever could.  Or maybe the best part is the post-catastrophic New York itself. A sizable chunk of a city ravaged by a weaponized virus has been meticulously created, and it looks and feels absolutely spot on. There are small details and nice touches everywhere, and exploring the alleys, stores and subways is constantly rewarded with little snippets of information that reveal the blight of the individuals caught up in increasingly dire circumstances.  The game doesn't shy away from its heavy subject matter. I'd say the worldview of The Division is surprisingly dour for a high-profile AAA blockbuster. The somber tone is disrupted only by the side mission voiceovers which try to add a dash of humor to the game, ending up sticking out like a sore thumb.  The environment tells a much better story than the main plotline, which is mostly concerned about shutting down various factions operating in the city and providing the players with more fodder to chew through. The shoot & loot gameplay of The Division manages to stay smooth and engaging although the enemy variation is minimal: Shooting guns just feels right, which is weird considering you'll usually have to unload a whole clip for a single bad guy to give up the ghost.  Moment-to-moment tactics never rise into a big role when playing alone, but jumping into a small group brings up the nuances of engagements better, with actual flanking moves and planning required, especially on the higher difficulty levels.  Praise must also be heaped upon the Snowdrop Engine, which is one of the most impressive pieces of graphical technology for the current generation. It might not be the fanciest engine, but the vistas it manages to consistently pull off are certainly impressive. Sound is not quite as great, and there's a lot of repetition in the audio that is somewhat jarring.  Anyhow, I quite enjoyed my time with The Division, playing both alone and in a group. The game nails the tempo of individual firefights, but more importantly it understands the value of quiet moments as well. Jogging along the deserted streets, just exploring and taking in the views remains my favorite thing in the game.  The Division is a solid cover-based loot shooter. It doesn't really bring anything new to the table; It just polishes an existing formula to a pleasing sheen. I think it's easily better than Borderlands, for example. Maybe that's because I found the subject matter way more compelling. It's a Tom Clancy game with the usual Tom Clancy gun/military/technology worship toned down. This post-apocalyptic world proved to be more interesting than anything Fallout 4 had to offer.

Ok I'm going to write the most honest review that I can without judging the game on the Day One massive f*ck up.   Let me say that this game can be a lot of fun with friends. If you're playing alone, you're going to have a tough time unless you team up with random people in the match making.   Think of this game like Diablo in the sense of playing with friends and the way the weapons and gear work. Color coded for rarity, stats, etc. That is the best way to describe the game.   This is NOT an MMO! Playing the normal side of the game, you will never see another player except when you enter a safe house (or if you are in a group with friends). The only time you might ever fight a human player is in the Dark Zone (DZ). That is the only time you will see another human player. Think of the DZ as the PVP area.  I highly recommend the game based upon the playing factor.  BUT!  I cannot recommend the game based upon the bugs. Yes the Day One f*ck up was stupid. Too many people trying to play the moment the game released crashed the server. But that isn't what I'm talking about.   Some players bought the game and couldn't even download the game. Others bought the game, downloaded it, but couldn't play it as they only had black screens.   Or you might be lucky like me. I can play the game... most of the time. Sometimes I'll get an entire day of 'Account Temporarily Unavailable'.  Then there are other bugs that happen with other games. Falling through the ground or getting stuck into something and can't get out forcing you to fast travel. Sometimes you can't complete a mission and are forced to restart the entire thing over multiple times until the game accepts that you have completed it.   I would give this game another couple patches before plopping down the full price for it.

Long long post, TLDR; game sucks bad.  Absolute Garbage of a game, starting out it is fun due to all the freeroam activities running around the city gathering stuff and enjoying the atmosphere. As the game gets closer towards end game, the story turns into a stupid rushed ending that makes absolutely no sense at all.   This game in theory was going to be a huge hit, by bringing together a shooting game with RPG mechanics but what it turned out was a complete pile of steaming piping hot crap because it implements the worst aspects of both genres. Players suffer from shooter mechanics of easily getting 1 shotted by the AI, while the constant spawn and zerg rushing of bulletspongeAI towards the player makes it near impossible to not bog down.   Having a dedicated machinegunner to suppress the AI doesnt work either because a) he will get 1 shotted by uber laser marksmen or b) get overwhelmed by the enemy because all the weapons in game is poorly balanced and machineguns seems to be shooting out spitballs, as of now there are only cookie cutter builds revolving around certain weapons (SMGs, Marksmen/snipers) because everything else simply doesnt work.   At endgame its just mindless grinding of extremely stale instances (camp in the pit for 15 waves APC mission) or near ridiculously amounts of sniper, mortar, machinegunner, shotgun zerg rushes (clear sky) nonsense missions. All the while having RNG work against you as it drops tons and tons of absolutely useless gear with useless stats. Instances at times bug out and after matchmaking for a pub game just to realize the gates dont open or the AI dont spawn.   The implementation of gear score in recent patches seemed like a great idea until you realize that pubs will constantly boot people with insufficient gearscore but at the same time gear score being nowhere near a good gauge of player skill. It is also buggy and at times the gear scores of my friends constantly fluctuate without them changing equipment.   All the best gear seems to be locked in the dark zone where forced PVP is encouraged, have not been in there too often, but the times I did stumble in to try to get some good blueprints ended up being lagfest or death due to cheaters/exploiters.   Absolutely stay away from this game unless you have too much money to burn, in that case go roll those notes into a cigar and smoke them or better still donate it to charity. EDIT #3 - Fixed Grammar and Typing Errors     The Game:  Tom Clancy's The Division (just 'the Division' for the remainder of this review) is a great little online RPG game by Ubisoft! I'm amazed too that Ubisoft was able to pull of making an entirely new franchise and not have it completely suck like many other Ubisoft games (Watch_Dogs for example).   Gameplay:  The Division plays great, in my opinion anyways, and I am playing it on the PC (Windows 64-bit). The controls (keyboard and mouse in my case) feel natural and 'correct'. The game does not feel 'choppy' or 'blocky' like most multi-platform TPS (Third Person Shooters). Most of the time the camera just feels all wrong when using the mouse, but not the Division so kudos to Ubisoft for making the game feel great on PC when using PC controls.  In addition to 'feeling' correct while playing on PC, the game actually plays correctly too. The only bugs I've ever really had were just latency bugs (I'd kill two enemies but the game wouldn't 'kill' them until suddenly all at once - this has only happened 4-5 times total and the 'lag' lasts no longer than 2 seconds tops).   Game Performance (PC):  The Division runs great on PC (in my case, right now an Alienware 18' laptop with SLI). I'm not running it at maximum settings on this laptop (though it does run at max settings on my desktop); either way however The Division looks great - regardless of the computer I'm on. The game doesn't seem to suffer from lagging and other performance issues like Console Games on PC (aka ♥♥♥♥ ports like GTA IV and even GTA V).    The Play 'Feel':  The way this game feels is pretty much covered in the above paragraph; however I may as mention it in specific detail here. The Division feels like an online RPG Third-Person-Shooter and on PC it feels like it was made for PC, again stuff I've already stated. As far as the way runs/feels/etc. though I will give it a seperate score for this. For being a decent game or even port (if it is) it doesn't feel bad so it gets  4 out of 5  stars for the 'Feel'.    Manhatten (PvE):  All of your non-PvP quests for leveling your standard level and whatnot takes place outside the 'Dark Zone' in the middle of the game's map. In this area you simply do PvE quests against NPCs, you don't end up fighting any actual players (PvP) until you are in the Dark Zone - which has its own leveling system versus the PvE leveling system (you level differently and they have no influence on each other).   The Dark Zone (PVP):  The Dark Zone is The Division's PvP Zone. Here player Agents can go 'rogue' and kill you; they usually do this while you are waiting for your extraction for 90 seconds after launching your flare. Not all agents have to go Rogue however; if you choose not to you instead, will be killing these rogue agents. My knowledge on The Division's Dark Zone isn't the most complete; however I am aware that once you shoot off your flare, there is an intense wait for gear/player extraction. Other players can see your flare shoot off and will come for you for the loot you're extracting; so be careful and if you can - go to the Dark Zone with friends (up to 4 people per group).    Overall:  Tom Clancy's The Division is a great Online (MMOish) Third-Person Tactical Shooter. In the non-Dark Zone areas it's a PvE game and once in the Dark Zone it's PvE with PvP thrown in as well. I must caution to watch out for higher 'Dark Zone' level players while you're a low level. They tend to kill you just because they can - half the time they don't even bother taking loot; or they'll steal all your loot but let you live - so be aware of that too. Otherwise I highly recommend The Division to anyone who is into the Tom Clancy series of games, or is into games with a realistic story, or just into online games (or third-person shooters). I should add that the maximum amount of players per 'Dark Zone' instance, I believe, is 24 players (including you and your teammates if you're with any). Either way, while that 90 seconds may be intense - it sure is fun waiting with your buddies to see just how much ♥♥♥♥ is going to go down!   Other Thoughts:  Other than what I've previously mentioned; I don't have much else to add to this review. I hope it was sufficient enough to help anyone out with making the decision of weather to get The Division or not. I'd say yes it's worth it - but me and all my buddies think it is. For those of you who aren't my buddies or me - just make up your own mind because nobody is better at giving you an opinion than yourself! ;)    Overall Score:  5/5 - An Excellent Ubisoft Title, and one of the rare few deserving of a full 5 stars. I love games with depth. RPGs, MMOs, Open world games, I mean don't get me started on those. But what I don't like, is when a game is marketed as one or more of the aforementioned genres. Yet fails in one or more of them. Is this an RPG? Well yes, in the same sense pokemon is, but even pokemon has more depth to it.  In 'The Division'; you gain experience and level up, get skill points which you can assign to a skill. So far so good. Textbook RPG right there. But the thing that bothers me is that it's so short on everything. You get three 'skill trees', which you can switch between, and adapt accordingly to the situation at hand, so you're not stuck with a choice. But it's shallow, In the end everyone can have the exact same skills, really, the exact same character. There so individualism, my character felt like exactly every other character. Did not feel personal at all. Not even the appearance feature has a wide variety as I saw myself pretty much everywhere. But I digress, I believe this was not their main focus, and I've seen that cosmetic items do exist.   So is it an MMO game? Yes, in the same sense that the Dark Souls-series is an MMO game. What I mean by that is, outside of the Safehouses and the Darkzone, you'll be alone, for all time, travelling from location to location. You'll spot NPCs form time to time, but that's about it. I compare it to Dark Souls-series in the way that even in Dark Souls you have some form of communication or at least contact with the other worlds, i.e. other players and it is NOT marketed as an MMO last time I checked. But in The Division there exist no such thing outside of the Safehouses and the Darkzone. So, MMO? Doesn't really feel like it, but I guess the term is so loose that it can be applied to this game. The true way to play this game, is to play it with others. Because New York is a really lonely place.   And of course, the open world aspect. What can I say? I don't think it's more open world than the rebooted Tombraider-series is. Don't get me wrong, I like Tombraider. The areas are big in that game, but linear, not really 'open'. Why, oh why, did most of the focus for the game go to visuals and world design? Sure, it looks stunning at times, except for those white/grey/black colours that you see everywhere. Exploration is useless. You might find some survival guide pages, some loot, maybe some other things I don't know. With only just short of 2h playtime, I don't really know if exploration contributes to anything later on, as in secret missions, items, NPCs, shops, etc. But what I did and regret now, was to explore. Found some enemies, got some loot, pretty standard. Went into building and apartments, found some canned food and energy bars. Sweet. Pretty much a win, right? Spending 5-10 min for an energy bar? Priceless, papa bless.   Now for some positive feedback on this title.   It has great combat, I fell in love with the combat so much. I noticed small details I didn't think about before. Mind you, I'm not a big fan of shooters, but I do love me some TPS. Enemies react to you pretty much instantly after engaging combat. There is barely ANY stealth.  But I noticed that you can sneak around a few covers/corners and if they didn't see you do this, they'll still think you are somewhere around the previous location. Which is a pretty fun mechanic and you can clear areas without taking a single hit; that is, if you get rid of the melee enemies first, then do some recon action.  This by far is the only positive thing I have to say about this game.   Crafting, pretty mundane from what I understood. Didn't do any of it, will thus not give my full opinion about it. Pretty standard crafting for any game really.  My biggest disappointment with this title. Was the lack of customization when it came to your characters appearence and skills. Think of it like XCOM: enemy unkown vanilla, where you had two 'trees' per class for your soldiers. While this game is honestly just one class, with different specializations which you can change whenever, so whatever.   People compare it to Diablo? Really? Path of exile too? Really? Mass effect? What?  Mass effect might've lacked in class depth but it did not lack in story, content, and most of all exploration.  Diablo and Path of exile, ARPGs to begin with. Gameplay not the same at all. So in what way are they similair? They're not in my opinion. Even Diablo and PoE rewards exploration. And they have a much greater depth in both story and customization.   Thoughts:  They shouldn't have had put The Division centered in New York. They should've done it in a ficitional city where laws could've been different. Model it after New York, whatever, but give the game something else than just plain combat, boring design, and simplified character depth. Futuristic elements, a 'what-if' historical scenario just something different. Innovative. Do I wanna see New York? No, I really don't. Do I want real-life conbat? Yes, but then again this gmae is TPs...  My score for this game is a LOW 2/10. Have never seen a cash dumbster and time waster like this for many years, and hope it'll be the last to come. I will officially NEVER purchase any other game developed by or published by Ubisoft.

Despite the launch day woes that EVERY major online game goes through, The Division is a fantastic game.  RPG elements blend well with gunplay in ways that are compelling and feel a bit tighter than other mash-ups, such as Borderlands.  Two buddies and I went and did one of the main missions for the game, Joe switched to heals and played with his sniper rifle. He provided spot heals and high damage on important targets.   Matt provided buffs with Pulse and Smart Cover.  And I used my turret and sticky grenade along with a LMG to get lots of attention and keep enemies pinned down.   Honestly, it felt great. I was able to Supress enemies (who took cover and received a 'Supressed' status) while my teammates moved to engage. We worked together and it felt like we were playing the demoes from E3, it was that flawless.  When they're not around, the game still feels great. Dropping in on friends and helping them with their missions is quick and easy.     The Division is a unique experience that is sure to upset some.   It isn't Gears of War. It isn't Destiny. It isn't Borderlands. It isn't Splinter Cell.   Gamers always cry for innovation, but when they get it this is the result. Regardless of how you might feel about The Division, it plays great, looks fantastic (on a wide range of settings), is very smooth with lots of details and polish.

Compare this to other RPG's than shooters, because this is exactly that: an RPG with gun elements. However, the gunplay is quite good and thus it feels like a shooter. The controls are tight; snapping into place when taking cover, vaulting over things, ADS and so on. If you master the auto-run function, the game truly becomes your playground.  The game isn't too grindy (comparing to other RPGs). You get good rewards- better wepons, outfits, armor, money, etc. It is very enjoyable to level up in this game, as I'm always looking to do missions. On this note, matchmaking is very useful and much more fun for doing missions. Plenty of side missions to do when you are underleveled for the story mission, which grant you lots of xp and rewards as well.  The Darkzone (PVP aspect of the game) is fun too. I recommend playing with friends, or if you are very trusting of people, playing with strangers. You get better loot, but it is much harder (enemies and other players). You can solo run in the Darkzone but being a higher level (gained in PVE) will make you last longer, as you have better weapons, you get better drops, and you actually have skills/perks/talents to use.  I very much recommend this game. It had bad reviews at the start (shaky launch, server problems), but most problems people had before dont seem to be an issue now. A massive amount of the hate that came from this game happened in its opening hours, when the load of such a massive player base made their servers crash. I'm of the school of thought that doesn't hold this against a company. Sure, it might be nice to have the servers ready but anyone who has sat through an MMO launch can tell you that these things happen. It doesn't detract from the game itself.   Probably the biggest perk so far of this game's launch is that the developers listen. They've fixed bugs as they've arisen, reworked gun balance issues, and have actively engaged in discussions on both their forum and on reddit itself.   Now the game itself is absolutely beautiful. IF, and that's a big if, your PC can run it on its maximum settings it looks stunning. E3 didn't do it justice. Even on high and medium settings, it is probably the most visually stunning game I've ever played. They just get the atmosphere right. Trash, dogs, people, all of them contribute to a beautiful world where you have to fight tooth and nail to get what you want.  If you buy this game looking for a well developed story, you're going to be disappointed. There aren't a whole lot of cutscenes and character development is pretty lackluster unless you look into your intel. Even then it's not amazing. With that said, it was never really advertised as this intense story driven game. You get what you need out of it. New York is burning, quite literally sometimes, and it's your job to put it out. They do a good job at making that known as soon as the prolouge finishes. From there, it's up to you to act as you see fit in order to fight through the different missions, build your base, and work on a cure alongside your fight to restore order and deal with the various criminal organizations throughout the game. It's not a massively complicated system but at the same time it allows for a massive amount of variation.  Take, for instance, the enemies. A lot of complaints about this game came from the enemies after people rushed into the game. I'm sorry but if you give the game a terrible review a day in without having even gotten through the missions or really even experienced the game, you're a bad reviewer. Back to my point, the enemies are far more varied than what they're credited with. Especially later on in the game. There are four distinct factions. Rioters, Ritkers, Cleaners, and the LMB. Each one fights differently and has to be approached different. Rioters fill the roll of low level mobs. They're not really to be fear and are easy at every level. Ritkers are ex-cons who favor brute force to tactics. Cleaners adore fire in all its forms and this shows in how they fight. The LMB is a PMC that uses tactics, grenade launchers, and even turrets to give them as much of an advantage as they can. All of these enemies can be found in different areas and, if you're unlucky, in the same place. They will fight each other as well as you and act very differently through every fight.   Crafting, looitng, and purchases in this game are all things that are still being worked on to ensure balance is brought to the game. With that said, they're all very much viable at this time. Crafting resources are easily gotten around the map and in the dark zone or even from deconstructing your weapons. Looting is fair and balanced with an RNG system.   The only gripe that I have with the game is the PVP, where you get punished pretty heavily for going rogue which removes pretty much all incentive to do so. As a result, PVP is pretty much non-existant as people are too afraid of losing money and DZ level to strike out against others as it leads to them being hunted down for their gear. I believe, however, they are looking into a way to balance this as well.  That's my review folks.   TL;DR version: Early reviews bad. Game good. Developers listen. Much wow. Such game.

Rinse, repeat.

The Division intrigued me from the second I began playing the Open Beta. The game is a true cover shooter, with heavy RPG elements. It reminds me quite a bit of Mass Effect, and I love Mass Effect. I looked at the game's store page curious as to the review status of this game and couldn't believe my eyes when I saw 'Mixed'. It's kind of upsetting, as the only reason for the negative reviews seems to be the server hiccup that happened at launch (which delayed it for maybe an hour - not really that big of a deal), and the fact that the game is a Ubisoft AAA title, which I can admit made me a little biased against the game as well.   But after playing through the story and hitting max level, and spending considerable time in The Dark Zone, I can guarantee that anyone who buys this game with the right idea of what they're getting into will enjoy it. First off, let me clear up what MMO means to The Division. The game is always online, and you can always be playing with other players. But outside of The Dark Zone, and if you're not in a group, you're essentially playing by yourself, as even the global chat is turned off unless you manually turn it on. So the game /does/ have a Single-player component. Though running through some of the missions on Solo can be a bit tough, it is possible, as I completed every mission this way initially.  The gameplay itself is extremely enjoyable and thrilling. The AI in the game is smart, and will outflank and outgun you if you're not careful and prudent in your own maneuvering. They can easily pin you down and flush you from cover if you don't do something to save yourself. The AI is brutal and deadly - and I love it. (Except the f*cking Riker / LMB Rushers. F*ck those guys.) You will be challenged by this game. It requires a lot of thinking and second to second planning on your part to win some fights. Every player, as they progress through the game, will unlock better gear and weapons - but also special skills that basically determine what they do during a fight. Things like shields, seeker mines, first aid machines, etc., can all be unlocked and used to help yourself and help your teammates (if you have any). Every skill can also be changed in some way by modding it to do different things, adding even more possible combinations. Everything about your character is determined by three basic attributes that can be modified only with the gear you're wearing: Firearms, Stamina, and Electronics. Firearms determines how much damage you do, Stamina how much health you have, and Electronics determines your Skill Power, which buffs your Special Skills (doing things like strengthing your ballistic shield / increasing damage of your Seeker Mine, etc.) It's really simple and easy to get the hang of. It's easy to completely swap your build based on what you think you need for a mission, and really easy to rebuild your character if you just don't feel like what you're doing is working, especially since there is a tool in the game that lets you reroll the stats of your gear for a couple thousand credits (which isn't much). Using this tool lets you not only choose precisely what you want to choose, but also lets you choose which outcome you want from a list that it produces. All in all, it's extremely well thought out, innovative, and fun to play around with.  The graphics, too, deserve some credit. The game runs really well on most systems, including mine, at high-ultra at 1080p. I'll admit, after the Beta, I was worried about the performance of the game. But it definitely improved for the release, something I was pleased to see. Everything in the game is beautiful and lifelike, even on lower settings.  So, not only do I recommend The Division, I highly recommend it. It's a game that deserves your purchase, and your time. And when you do decide to descend into The Division, look me up. This is an in depth review of The Divison, it covers story, gameplay, graphics, endgame and PVP. I will rate each catigory out of 10.  Story: The story is fairly deatailed and interesting, I was invested in it the whole way. Nothing groundbreaking, but not terrable. 7/10  Gameplay: The gameplay is very repetitive and challenging. There are now special bosses with weakspots(exept the head!!!) and all the enemys are bullet sponges. The side missions are also very repetitive, they are usualy, go up to the objective, kill bad guys, singnal JTF, wait for JTF, fight more bad guys while waiting, JTF arrives, clear out rest of enemys, beat the mission. However, the gameplay is super addictive, and you always want that better loot. 7/10  Graphics: This game is beutiful, one of the best looking games I have seen in a long time. Everything is so detiled, You can even shoot out the tires on most of the static cars around Manhattin! It also has a day/night cycle and snowstorms, snow even builds up on your charictor when he/she is out side, and melts when inside. And the best part, you don't need a beast machene to run this game, I have a GTX 860M and I have no problem running this game. 9/10  Endgame: The endgame is essentualy running around the world/dark zone to complete side missions and get better loot. 5/10  PVP: The Dark Zone is where you go to get better loot and kill other players for xp. The penaly for going rouge(attacking another player unprovoked) is so high that no one kills eachother. 5/10  Overall, I would give this game a 7.5/10

I was drawn in on the hype of this game by strategic teasers and well done developer gameplay videos. This game gave me hope and appreared to be a fresh breath of air for the genre. The thought of exploring a post apocolyptic New York and being able to do whatever you wanted had me extremely excited for this game. But instead here is what you get from this game - A linear, HIGHLY instanced, highly repeditive grind fest that will leave you wanting more.  Here is the entire game in short. Get mission. Go to mission. Find bad guys. Duck in cover. Wait for bad guys to stop shooting. Emerge from cover and shoot them. Move up. Repeat 1,354,754 times.  No dynamic events that impact the game. No real exploring as all missions tell you where to go and even give you a line on your screen to follow just to make sure you don't stray off. Think you will see other players wandering around? NOPE.. it is all instanced. The moment you leave the safe house you are put into your own instanced world void of any real players.  I thought this was going to be an open world game full of exploring and random firefights. Instead it is the complete opposite.

Honestly, the Division is a really hard game to review...  Let me try and make this easy for myself and everyone;  Positives ----------- - Beautiful graphics, even on low quality - Great performance, even on lower end PCs (A friend of mine can run it on his potato PC~ XD) - Immersive story that really encourages continued play  Middle Ground (Neither positive or negative) ---------------- - Gunplay isn't the best, but it's not horrible either... It's decent for a 3rd person shooter and decent for a tactical cover shooter and good as a story-centric MMO - Abilities are good, but feel lacking  - Weapon availability is good, as there are many different kinds of weapons, but there are far too few weapons to say that the weapons are a positive... - Character customization is mediocre... It works as a start, but it leaves me wanting more (Only about 6 styles of hair? And I can't use the same style on a second character?) - Character outfits are quite varied, but again are lacking some things that other games include by default... (Why does every hat I wear remove my characters ponytail?) - Dark Zone... A place of hackers and a place of nice people who don't kill you simply because you're another player... I've seen both sides of the DZ and it's not that bad, if you know what time of day to play...  Negatives ------------- - Poor server stability means you spend a great amount of time either lagging or being timed out... Ubisoft has improved these issues somewhat, but they still persist. Any other company would have had these problems fixed within the first week or so... - Hackers are still a problem... Bans have been slow coming and now perma-bans are going out, but it might still not be enough... - Exploitability is the core issue with the Division. Apparently Ubisoft used a client-side system to determine correct values for player gear, damage, health, etc. leading to massive issues with hackers/cheaters - Bugs and quality control seem to still have escaped Ubisofts team... Again, they've gotten somewhat better, but any other company would have fixed massive exploit bugs within a few hours/days of the community finding them. - Poor loot/crafting system means that players are constantly left farming missions to get decent gear and materials to make more gear. Also, the use of a currency system to buy blueprints for crafting means that you have to grind even more...   To conclude, The Division is a game I would recommend. It will take some getting used to, but it is a fun game. If you want a game with a story, buy it. If you want a grindy MMO, buy it. If you want a Destiny-esque experience for PVP/PVE, don't buy it...  POST 'UNDERGROUND' DLC UPDATE ---------------------------------------------------------- The DLC is focused on breathing life back into the PVE side of the game. Adding new weapons, another few gear sets, and a completely new 'area' of procedurally generated, repeatable missions, 'Underground' is definately a step towards getting the Division closer to what it should have been from the begining.
Personally... I really enjoy this game. This is a definite 'thumbs up' from me! :)

I don't quite understand all of the negative reviews. Perhaps gamers bought this game thinking that it was going to be something different than what it actually was.   For me, I typically do not get into M M O's. I have had poor experiences with other titles and so, I typically stay on the action shooter side of the spectrum.....COD, BF4 etc.   I think this game has a nice balance between action and looting. If you are looking to just drop in and start shooting, this is not the game for you. But, there is plenty of action in the missions and side missions to keep you happy. But, you have to pay attention to what you are doing. Its not like some zombie M M O where you kill whatever enemies are there, take the loot and move on. You have to actually plan your way through the missions to accommodate ammo usage/availability, safe zones etc. The last thing you want is to be stuck out there without any ammo or med kits. Also, you have to be aware of your level. If you are level 10 and you are trying to complete a level 16 mission, you are not going to make it no matter how hard you try.   There are a lot of details in this game, perhaps more than most people realize. Maybe that's why the nay sayers have given this game a thumbs down. But, if you like details and have the patience, you can really have some fun. If you have friends who also like that, then, the game can truly have some glorious moments.   Like any new release, there are a few bugs that will need patching. The graphics are very good. I play the game on high and ultra with a slightly better than mid level laptop (GTX 870m GPU, i7 Haswell @ 3,4 GHz, 12 Gig Ram).   The interface is good. However, it will take some time to get used to all the ways your character can interface with the world. If you are coming from the FPS world and this is your first M M O (COD, CSGO etc), getting used to the controls and using them efficiently during game play will be challenging, at first. I you are a mouse/keyboard player, I would recommend at minimum a 5 button mouse. If you have a gaming mouse, then, things will be easier. If you are using a controller, you may find combat to be a bit challenging in terms of target acquisition. I would highly recommend putting the controller down for this game.  As the game develops over the next few months, I am sure any glitches/bugs will be ironed out along with some other issues such as nerfing and buffing weapons etc.   As of right now, there does not appear to be much in the way of anti-cheat measures. From what I understand, you have to actually record someone cheating and then email it to the devs. I could be wrong about that. But, that's my understanding. But, since this is not a P2P platform and is server based, I am sure part of the near future developments will be some sort of anti cheat protocol.   At the end of the day, I can think of far worse ways to spend $60.  UPDATE - 7/5/16  We are now 3 updates in to The Division experience and I must say that my opinion of the game is still the same. But, I have since adopted a rather tarnished opinion of the game devs. The released updates thus far have added new content to the game, however, each update has been littered with bugs and glitches. The issues with each release are so bad, its almost as if the updates are not being tested prior to release. Needless to say, the issues that are associated with each release are not what anyone would expect from the a triple A studio.  Aside from the updates, the devs cannot seem to find a formula that adds balance to the game. Instead, they have made a series of changes that actually worsens what little balance there is. For instance, the devs have introduced higher level NPC's, yet, they nerfed some of the best weapons and gear sets thus addiing a measure of difficulty to the game that borders on impossible, especially for solo players.   Each update has introduced new gear sets that have consistently gotten worse. They have added talents and featurres to the new gear sets that in some cases are literally useless. One gear set actually has a talent where the player can use special bullets and not only does the talent give those bullets to each of his team mates, it gives the bullets to enemy agents as well!!   There are many more examples of where the devs have made some very qurestionable decisions that are far too numerous to mention here. Despite all of its shortcomings, the game is actually fun to play (when it actually works properly). However, I do not hold much faith that this game will enjoy a lengthy life span given all of the issues that the devs can't seem to correct.   This game is great example of an excellent concept that has been poorly executed. Purchase at your own risk.

First things first: Yes, there was a downgrade to the visuals BUT the game still looks amazing, textures, models, lighting and effects are all beautiful.   There are no loading screens apart from when you first start the game and when you fast travel. The game is seamless, from joining with friends, starting missions, entering buildings and even entering PvP.  I played both the closed and open betas for this game and enjoyed my time with them and in my 18+ hours within the full game from writing this review I am still loving it.  The gunplay is satisfying, figuring out different gear and skill combinations is interesting, the co-op experience is amazing and the PvP is fun, exciting and tense.   There is end-game content available for players that reach the maximum level of 30, complete all story missions and side missions. You can do PvP/Looting within the Dark Zone, you can do daily missions which provide better gear and other loot. You can even do Challenge mode which can provide you with Legendary loot.  It's a great game and a great experience. Definitely not one to miss, especially with the free updates and content and expansions coming in the near future.
