Pros:  It looks nice ( when it is not rendering everything a few feet from your face)  ----------------------  Cons:  Character customization: Basically dose not exist. Which I think would be something an 'MMO' would have.  Story *spoiler*:  Generic and has been done many times. Must help save humanity ( What is left of it anyways) from a doomsday virus. Now with the help of a doctor who thinks you are worthless, an electrician that is an ♥♥♥♥♥, and some cop who is the leader or something... I forget really   inventory:  Sometime it won't scroll though my items and will gets stuck. I have to spam random buttons just to exit the inventory screen just to get it to somewhat work properly. Also, the perk menu keeps saying I have new stuff that can be done when nothing new can be done with said perks.  Dark zone: Anyone who ends up joining this game late will just struggle nonstop from players that can kill you in 2 to 3 shots. While my sniper rifle with about 70k dps only does about 4k damage on a body shot to a player and they do about 30k to me. I made the error of thinking that my ballistic shield, with almost 230k HP, could take a few bullets If it even defends me at all. It turns out players can still shoot ya in the face even though in your pov it looks like your players head is behind it. Oh, and the pistol seems worthless fighting players only doing 400 - 600 damage.  If you do manage to get to an extraction point with some half decent items, if you are lucky, then check your map to make sure no player killers are around. After that, go hide somewhere and wait for someone else to start an extraction somewhere else. This should distract anyone looking for easy loot and should hopefully give you enough time to extract your items.  Trying to kill an player killer when he is around buddies that haven't killed anyone (or they re-spawn to help there friend out), will try to body block your shots to make you go rouge. Which just kills the whole dark zone for me really (not that it had much going for it anyways). Why should i be punished for trying to kill a rouge agent because someone runs in front of my gun to stop my bullets? A+ mechanics...  The dark zone adds nothing new to the game other than the possibility of broken PVP and the same PVE with more baddies that take even more damage than the last batch.   Ballistic Shield is very buggy : If you happen to deploy this while standing to close to and object and a wall, you may clip though the wall and fall into the void. Or you get stuck and have to kill your self with grenades because you can't fast travel while stuck in combat.... Also, it won't deploy while RUNNING, but it will still go on cool down. Not like I needed to get away from the AI with the shotty anyways.  Sometimes, my gun won't even fire its bullets while this shield is deployed. OR even Worse, it will fire the bullets, but will hit the ballistic shield because it is bugging out.  Another thing with the damn shield, ( yes it is that damn buggy), I can't switch my weapons SOMETIMES if i go to use cover. No clue why, other than lack of testing because it happens so easily.  Challenge mode: Don't even try to solo this bs. It is like trying to fight every AI as an endgame boss bullet sponge.  AI: Don't count on the JTF to help you at all really. The only thing the JTF are good for is dying so you don't die. They rarely kill any of the enemies, and only seem to be a distraction to them. The enemy AI is not that bright. They will either charge at ya or run in the same patterns over and over again. 'Bosses' do the same thing as well.  The mini radar: This thing will lie to you, especially in the dark zone. Thinking that you have found loot because it shows up on the radar, then see that the box can't be open for some reason. No explanation why the ordinary box can't be open ( and no, it is not the key or DZ level boxes). Also, don't trust the scanning ability, the AI will spawn behind you anyways for a surprise attack, even though only '1' treat was detected.  Civilians: You will see the same animations for them over and over again. They do nothing special, other than take your items unless you move weirdly. Then they get mad and basically call you the worst person on earth. Also, there is this one civilian who is just moving boxes around. I happen to bump into him ( because i am a jerk) and the boxes just vanish. It is like he had no boxes at all and goes on acting like the rest of the idiot civilians.  One other thing that bothers me, you can't kill Civilians. I blew one up on mistake because i shot some AI's backpack and the civilian just runs out of the explosion like nothing happened to him. Not much else to say about that really.  The fun missions: Go from point A to point B killing the same wave of enemies. Or defend an area so the useless JTF don't die. If defending the JTF is not for you, how about stopping a drug deal going down by killing everyone, then defending the drugs from being blown up... Would that not be a good thing though?  Anyways, missions are boring because you do the same damn thing every time in a new area.   Selecting grenades and snack foods:  I haven't even used the food based items because I don't want to use my med-kits by mistake. You have to hold down the heal button in order to bring up a selecting wheel that you have to use with the mouse in order to pick the item you want. Same goes for the grenades as well... takes up a ton of time just to do one simple thing. The selecting wheel it self seems a little finicky as well, so you will probably pick the wrong item.  Incendiary/explosive rounds: After you select one of these from the selecting wheel, you have a chance to deal fire or explosive damage. To bad it seems so random that these bullets can't be relied on to do what they are meant to do. Bonus points if the explosive rounds decide to work when the bad guys get in your face. ---------------------------- conclusion: I have played better FTP (Free To Play) games that had more customization and variety of enemies than this 60$ game even offers. Even worse, the DLC they are adding should have been part of the game to begin with to even come close to justify the 60$ price tag. You would think that with about 3 or 4 years of development that this game would have more content than what it has now.

First the bad.  - Mediocre standard run of the mill apocalypse style story. It doesn't really go anywhere or make the virus feel dangerous or anything of the sort for your gameplay. It's just a thing that's there, and contaminated areas might as well be contaminated with cooties. It's a supervirus that can spread trough air, water, contact etc etc.. And someone did it because Y and group X now tries to do the right thing.  - Still has a few bugs here and there that can require a restart. Mind you, during the time I've played it, I ran into bugs maybe 3-4 times.  - Still has connection issues during the time when the bulk of the US gaming population hops on. I'm based in Europe and have played with people from all over the world already, so it doesn't look like the game is region locked at all.  Now for the good.  - I really really enjoy the gameplay of it. It's simplistic, clean and well executed.  - Easy to use crafting system. You get 5 materials with 3 qualities. You can upgrade 5 lower tier for a higher tier, it's easy to collect them and crafting an item only requires 2-3 different materials. No need to craft a bolt system, stock, barrel, etc etc etc to make one gun. Just gather the mats and make it. You can also deconstruct loot you get to turn it into crafting materials.  - I really enjoy the darkzone areas and the pvp aspect included. Going rogue on your own is nearly impossible, unless there are just not alot of people online. If you want to play the big bad wolf, get a group of 3 others, find a good spot to defend and go HAM. And if you loose, you're going to loose out on quite a bit of XP, DZ cash and DZ keys. I REALLY like this bit, because it means you actually have to think about when it's worth trying and when it's not. It means that the run of the mill duchebags that just try and shoot you for funsies usually get put down really fast. It also means that people that plan ahead and form their own little 4 man hunting squad, can do really really really well and stack up a ton of XP for it.   The coop part of the darkzone is amazing as well, because more often than not, you'll end up in a group with just a bunch of 3 random people that usually turn out to be decent folk. Just use your voicechat and communicate to people, and you're bound to make friends out there in the DZ. But for the love of god, turn your mic to push to talk.  - Endgame content. Okay so there's not a great deal of this in teh game yet.. But what I've seen so far has been amazing in terms of gameplay. You can redo missions on challenging difficulty, which bumps all enemies up to level 32 and makes them elites. It also boosts the number of enemy spawns, pumps up their damage to the level where 1 shotgunner getting behind your group can completely decimate you. It's HARD. The difficulty curve from hard to challenging is insane and it's why I love it. It REQUIRES teamwork, cooperation, working together to overcome the enemies. And you get rewarded for it in the end. There's just something about how it all comes together, the gameplay, the random groups, the teamwork that comes from it all.. It's just all very satesfying.  - Item system. Again, I really like this because it's simplistic, yet complicated. It's very easy to get into it, to understand what to do and what not to do. To realize that you can build pretty much whatever, and have it work if it's your playstyle. You can be a glass cannon, you can be the tanky brawler or you can be the tech guy that CC's and blows everything up, or the one that heals everyone.. the sniper, the glass cannon shotgunner that abolishes players in the blink of an eye.. It all comes together and allows you to be exactly what you want to be. It's classless and one moment you can be set up as a glass cannon sniper, but switch out your gear, talents and abilities, and now you're a tanky healer. Or a whatever. Combine stuff on the fly and build it all around your own playstyle. That you get all options open to you without having to arbitrarily figuring out which spesific class suits you best, just works. It might mean there's less replayability in that you don't need 1 of every class but at the same time, the game doesn't feel limiting.  Overall I've had a really good time with this game so far, and I got exactly what I expected out of it. For the price, you'll get a good amount of hours out of it all and that alone makes it worth the price, I think. Moderate your expectations and realize that until more content get put in, you'll probably not have more than 50-60 hours of gameplay before you run out of stuff to do and have pretty good and optimal gear for your playstyle. But that's better hours/price value that a lot of other AAA games have come up with, and given that there's going to be much more content in it as time goes on.. I'd say it's worth it.

Never really got a chance to play the beta, so I didn't have any previous experience/bias towards this game at release. That being said, Been playing for a short time now and what I've seen I really like so far. Sure the AI could be a bit better in terms of tactics; and I would love it if while you were wandering around the city, you got ambushed by enemies in building windows or on accessible rooftops. While it doesn't have that ambush mechanic there are scattered IEDs, which does add to some tension in some areas; but it'd be better if enemies attacked after they went off.  I wish there was a jump and crouch function, meaning that I would like a key to assign to a jump and crouch function, since I'd probably hop around on top of vehicles like an idiot in open world type scenarios.  The combat mechanics are pretty solid with each weapon (and higher level weapon of the same, i.e. Police M4) having their own unique stats and pros/cons. All of the hats, jackets, shirts, pants, boots, and scarves are cosmetic so there's no need to worry about finding the 'right' one to build up your character; as they're more for looks than performance. Items like kneepads, gloves, backpacks, vests, etc do have an impact on your character stats so you also have to balance them like you do with your weapons.  Mission variety can be a bit repetitive as far as side missions go, but I honestly don't mind as I've done but a few of them as I mostly wander around and find all the little things that you can find (mostly cosmetic items or weapons). Weapon customization is pretty cool, with various grips, magazines, muzzle attachments, and sights/scopes. Haven't really messed with gear mods yet so I don't know what to say on that.  As an NA player, had to wait a little while for the servers to launch correctly after release, and have some issues with performance as it uses up a lot of my gpu (not the absolute best but also not the absolute worst). A couple crashes and some server disconnects, but nothing major and something that should be expected on a freshly launched game of the MMO variety.  At any rate, this is my opinion on the game, my first impressions and I'll leave you to make up your own mind toward this game. Watch some youtube vids, watch some streams of your friends if they play it, and come to your own conclusion rather than listening to the tirades of people who hate connection issues or Ubisoft in general. I don't play a lot of their games mostly because I either couldn't afford them most times or haven't been able to since I had a low tier gaming laptop I used.  TL;DR version,  Gameplay is good, some things could be better, small details in my opinion. Server issues at start with a couple crashes, but overall I'd give it a 15/10 since I'm a fan of open world games, and this game takes that genre to a nice level I've been wanting.

You like comfort foods right? The Division is the comfort food video game equivalent. Everything in the game, from the shooting mechanics, the cover system (which is one of the best I have experienced), the storyline, the levelling and gear system has all been done before. But The Division does it really well.  The graphics are pretty good. I won't comment on performance because I have a 980ti and there hasn't been a game that I can't play on high with a smooth frame rate, but needless to say it runs nicely. The only bad thing I can say about the graphics is that I see a few glitches every now and then, that are in no way detrimental to the experience.   Throughout the game, you can pick up bits of 'evidence' that further explain the story. These are images from drones, phone recordings and 'echoes' which are reconstructed scenes from history. They provide a little more insight into the story. The videos are really well done, to the point where some even seem terrifying. As in, wow as humans we really did this to each other? The audio recordings are good too, you really get to feel how scared people were just as the outbreak started.  The story is your typical apocalyptic-♥♥♥♥-just-got-real type story. The characters in the game are well voiced and none of them have really stood out as lame or over the top. Although the story makes it seem like survival is of the utmost importance, it really doesn't feel like that when playing the game. I have never felt as if I am in any danger, and I am free to roam about the city, whether I'm in the dark zone or not. Sure there are some people out to kill me (including players, if you're in the dark zone) but if they kill me, so what? I don't really lose anything and I respawn at a safe house. Then I just jump back in and try again.  The gameplay consists mostly of hiding behind something and shooting when you can. It's a lot of fun, but definitely repetitive. Each fight is mostly the same, regardless of whether you change your abilities or weapons - none of this seems to drastically affect your playstyle, which is my main complaint for the gameplay. Levelelling up seems to have decent progression, but once you get to level 15, it seems mostly the same. With that said, I am still enjoying the game, just due to the fact that everything is so well made. The complete package, although nothing innovative, it still just as enjoyable to play. Much like every time you eat a BLT.  Overall if you're looking for something innovate and original that redefines the genre, you might want to look elsewhere. But if you're looking for a game with solid mechanics (despite being a little repetitive), a decent story with good acting and good levelling/progression, this is the right game. One final note I'd like to add is - play the game with friends. You can totally play by yourself with no problem, but friends, or at least joining up with people online make the game much more fun, especially when you play the missions on the harder difficulty.  8/10 [for those that like ratings].

Alright I'm going to try and give this the most objective review I can. I'll start off with an overall rating of 8/10. And now I'll give you the why. After playing the beta for a few hours I was really unsure about whether or not this was just another overhyped game. I'm about 13 hours into the game (would be playing now but server is down for maintenance, that's just part of playin an MMO) and I have really enjoyed it so far.   Graphics- Great, I have a good rig, not a super computer but I can run everything on ultra at about 50 fps, maybe a bit more. The atmosphere is well done and character models look pretty darn good. I would say that if you're PC is three or four years old that it might struggle on the higher settings.  Gameplay - The gameplay is maybe a step above good. Missions have been fairly repetitive with the exception of the main story but shooting up baddies with a large array of guns is enjoyable enough so that the side quests are still fun. Controls are pretty smooth so no complaints there.   Story - Again, like gameplay it's good, maybe not stellar. That being said I'm not even halfway done with the main story line and have yet to do anything in the dark zone. Overall it's fairly immersive and if you take the time to find the evidence (cell recordings, camera footage etc.) as you run around it adds a nice touch. The world itself feels very much like one that has just experienced a large scale shutdown of society and I'm curious to see what the rest of the story reveals.   MMO things - I've grouped up for a few missions and it is enjoyable to do so. Haven't played with a group of friends yet and I imagine that can only make things even better. Crafting is pretty straightforward but good. The items so far have been useful but I hope endgame crafting steps things up a notch. Although you have the freedom to go pretty much wherever you wish, there aren't a bunch of other players running around with you unless you're in a group. This is nice because you aren't fighting over mobs etc but it does make the world seem kind of empty (this does add to the post apocolyptic feel of the world though). Plenty of loot but hopefully will be more world drops in dark zone. Customization is pretty good with a decent array of talents, abilities, and perks. Character customization on the other hand is rather lackluster.   As for things I don't like there haven't been any glaring issues or things I just can't stand. The exp grind is definitely not the most engaging but it's good enough. To be honest I don't have too many negative things to say.  My final thoughts are these. Is the game fun? Absolutely yes! It's engaging and fairly immersive and the smooth controls and variety of ways to blow your enemies to bits has been a blast, no pun intended. Again, I give it an overall 8/10 and I am happy with my purchase.

This game is a lot of fun and I would highly recommend it. Here is why I feel that the game is good, made into a nice short list with pros and cons listed.  Pros + Loot - modern firearms is an angle that hasn't been hashed and rehashed yet. + Character Customization - TONS of clothing options and items to make your character feel unique + Third person shooter mechanics in an MMO  + Interesting story in the Tom Clancy Universe + PvP and PvE integration in Dark Zones + Highly replayable  Cons - Server Issues - a lot of people have been experiencing issues with the servers but, from my perspective, most of those appear to have been fixed. - Texture glitches - sometimes an area won't render properly even though I know my computer can handle it. - Character creation - fairly generic with not a lot of diversity. You spend a lot of time doing it and if you're not used to MMOs, it can be really boring. There is fast-travel but you're still running 90% of the time to your destination.  All in all, a very fun game and I thoroughly enjoy it. I've been enjoying The DIvision so far. After 11 hours in, I think I've got a pretty good feel for it. The game plays, essentially, like a post-apocalyptic Destiny (which isn't NECESSARILY a bad thing). That is, it's a loot-centric shooter in an open world,   Sadly, teh game's open world, while quite open, feels relatively devoid of life. Unless in a mission area, a contaminated zone, or at an encounter site, there aren't too many things to shoot, and civilians are generally few and far between as well it feels like. Fitting for a plague-ravaged NYC, yes, but also kind of disappointing for a game.  The missions, however, feel rather solid, with a fine variety and a decent level of difficulty that is tuned almost perfectly, it feels like, to group-play, as well the game should. Solo, however, several mission segments (namely the rather frequent 'defend this area from wavse of enemies' sections) can feel overwhelming if played alone. With a group, or even just one person as your companion, the game takes on an entirely new dimension that's just... The only word for it really is, wonderful: as your tactical options are increased exponentially. Complex and true-to-life tactics are very viable in teh game for those that want to try them out.  The gunplay feels pretty solid and enjoyable. Each gun feels and handles somewhat differently, and they are quite customizable with between one and four enhancement slots available depending on the type of gun (sights, magazine, barrel-attachment, and muzzle), allowing you to fine-tune your weapons into whatever you feel is most appropriate. A fifth slot, for weapon paint-jobs, is available as well, but they don't appear to have any meaningful effect on the weapon, and are purely cosmetic. The variety there, however, seems to be rather lacking as I've seen only one paint scheme, and that is unlocked via UPlay points, recieved by completing various achievements and milestones in the game that you can exchange via the UPlay option on the menus for cosmetic and out-of-game bonuses like soundtracks or concept art, mostly.  The story's pretty rote and predictable from what I've seen. Elite soldiers go in and disappear into the plague-ridden city. A second group is sent in, and you're part of that as you try to unravel the twin mystery of what happened to your comrades as well as, more importantly, restore order to the city and maybe, just maybe track down and bring the man responsible for the plague to justice. I know some might complain of spoilers, but really, it's so formulaic I doubt anyone's REALLY going to be surprised that those are the goals.  Ubi seems to have learned, as well, from the disaster a few years ago that was Assassins Creed Unity as well as Far Cry 4 and WatchDogs; meaning that The Division runs pretty handily. At least in my experience. The only issues I had were when I first launched the game some issues with ane xtended black-screen in the first minutes after the midnight release (presumably some sort of synch error with UPlay locking me out of the game despite allowing me to load up), and later on two server-desynchs caused - also that same night - by server strain it would seem. There were minor issues too with rewards not showing up in the vendor immediatesly; but that was fixed relatively quickly and I've long since recieved my pre-order stuff.  On the whole, the game is pretty solid and well-worth a look if you want a nice party-based shooter for PC. It looks pretty good, plays solidly.

You know... I was really on the fence with this one. Took part in the beta and had a fantastic time. Had quite a few compatibility issues and whatnot to sort out but they were all easy fixes. The main release has been improved in this regard and that's exactly what needed to happen.  Ubisoft went above and beyond with detail; graphics-wise I'm really impressed with all the options and how well it suits lower end computers instead of just catering to the highest bar. Nvidia Surround at release is something that isn't too common these days and I'm happy to see support.  Gameplay is incredibly fun and while it may not be the most immersion riddled game around, I am constantly looking for firefights and chances to get that shiny new piece of gear. Most people who say it's repetitive probably aren't a fan of hack and slash games like Diablo. This game is not meant to be the most realistic, it is in fact an RPG, and while it may have a grind for gear, the progression is constant and makes almost every new drop a step further. This game is not CoD nor was it meant to be compared to as such.   Content is another complaint I keep hearing about and quite honestly there is more than enough to keep me occupied for months perhaps years once expansions start to drop. There are plenty of main missions that make you progress through the levels and want to explore new areas of the city. The Dark Zone, while a bit formidable and menacing at first has become quite a lot of fun either alone or with a group and should be avoided like the plague concidering you have much higher drop chances from enemies.  The leveling can be a bit of a grind at times but do some missions and you'll get pulled right in. I actually commend Ubisoft for taking a chance with something different and challenging and am overall impressed with the game.  In my opinion this is the kind of rejuvenation and change the gaming industry needed by stepping out of the box.   I give it a 8.5/10. If your thinking about getting it but are straying due to the reviews, I say just try it; there is a reason Steam allows for returns ;P

It took me a couple of days to warm up to this game, but in all actuality, it's actually rather fun. I had to be told up front that Ubisoft didn't develop the game - they just published it. That did sway my favor toward buying it, because ... well, after a few bombs and some shady practices involving distribution, DRM shenanigans and the ever-invasive and seldom welcome necessity of installing uPlay (ugh), that brand and me aren't on great terms.   Once I got past that, however, and I sat down to play the game with some friends? I had a blast. It's a very atmospheric game that really conveys a disaster in a modern urban area very well. No weird, quirky characters, no BS, no real fluff - just you, your mates and your guns against a whole crap load of people who want you dead. And it's fun carving through that.  The gameplay puts an emphasis on tactics and creates hectic situations that can be legitimately frustrating when first approached, creating several panic scenarios. But as long as you and your partners are around the same level, nothing is ridiculously overpowered or difficult; quite the contrary, even. When you start investing in your gear and skills, YOU become the most dangerous thing on the streets. You still only get a few shots before your health bars evaporate, but that's usually enough to wake you up from a long walk down a city street overflowing with trash bags, rats and disheveled cars before you duck behind some cover and start figuring out what to shoot. It almost gets catharic after a while, when you've adapted your play style, gotten comfortable and dug in - you feel like a gristled veteran who's weathering a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ scenario and doing a very specfic job while folks back at your base of operations handle logistics.   You're the task op. You're the guy out there getting ♥♥♥♥ done. And it shows and conveys that very well.  Story's simple enough and handled in a way that's at least interesting and down-to-earth enough to be enjoyable. The recordings you pick up sound like actual people talking, not like the laughable deadpan snarkers in Prototype 2 or the super gruff and grit-blooded supersoldiers like in Metal Gear. You're all people in a complete crapstorm, and you get to see and hear how people are weathering it. Some do better than others. Hell, hearing a few of the Rikers and Cleaners talk about their people and experiences even made me bust out laughing - there's some great potential for black comedy in this game, and they throw in just the right amount to mix things up.  There are a lot of heartwarming moments, too, if you care to find them. Your base turns into a rather nice and calming shelter for the survivors that wander to it, and the upgrades are described as things people would actually need in a crisis - from quarantine and medical wings to water purifiers to recharge centers for people's smartphones. People in those situations want to contact their loved ones if they're displaced or living abroad - and that's a nice touch of realism. It keeps things from feeling too gloomy.  That said, there are some REALLY gloomy bits. Like, REALLY dark. When I said you hear about survivors and the insurgents dealing with things in a lot of ways? This game doesn't shy away from the dark stuff. Hell, one recording even detailed a veteran Riker giving advice to a new recruit on how to subjugate groups of survivors, giving details like getting children to comply by shooting their dogs if needed. That's dark - but that's real. It's little touches like this that make the game all the more atmospheric.  Game still has its flaws, though. You'll get stuck on cover and take a few cheap shots fairly often until you get the controls down, and even then, the game tends to think you're stuck to your cover like glue. Pulling away from it in a pinch is frustrating at times. The side missions are a bit repetitive, but there's no real grind - you can max out your base well before anything gets too boring. Your mileage may vary, but hell, that's how it felt to me.  Bottom line, though? It's a good game. Opting in for the season pass bumps the price up to around $100, though, which is completely insane. Holy hell, is that insane. Like, good flipping GOD. The game's good and all, but even with everything I've said up above, I STILL have a hard time completely justifying shelling out a hundred bucks for the game and the season pass! Pick that up only if you try the game and like it.  tl;dr - Game's alright, story's solid, very atmospheric, good combat, great with friends, side missions can be repetitive, EFFIN' EXPENSIVE

So this is an edited review. My last review I was only level 10 and had only played a few hours. Now im level 25 and have played 35+ hours. Which isnt alot compare to some but still. And for those that may not read this entire review, GET THE GAME!!! It is Awesome!! It is Everything an open world, RPG, third person shooter should be. Customization, Guns, and Explosions. What else do you need?? But for a post apocalyptic world, there are no zombies. Hopfully in a future DLC they will add some sort of Zombie.   I cant really list cons to this game. Im not that picky of a gamer. Just give me a gun and something to blow up and im happy. But.....a problem I experienced is when I went to play it my first time the screen was black. So I googled it and everyone said to fix the resolution, so I changed the resolution and I havnt had that problem since. And my display driver kept shutting down, so I had to do a little computer maintenance and My display driver hasnt shutdown since. So really the only problems Ive had were on my end and not the game. But that is really what all the negative reviews are about any way, people complaining about techical issues that they could fix with a little computer know how.    The only con that can think of is the Level cap........Im already level 25. So im only 5 levels away from the level cap. I had hoped that is would take a little longer to reach level 30. Here in a month everyone will be level 30. So if we dont get a DLC that raises the level cap then it could get really boring really fast.   There are a few aspects of the game that I really enjoy. I love the gun customizations and loadouts plus the skills. There is a gun and skill for every kind of player. With the gun mods you can turn an average gun into a great gun and specialized gun into a superior gun. You just have to find the right mods. It does have a decent story that you can follow and tons of missions and side missions. And even if you dont want to do those you can just explore.   Also the gun mechanics are very realistic. When you fire, the gun does not just make a sound and the reticule stays in the same spot like COD. There is RECOIL. Much like BattleField. Controling that recoil takes some getting used to. And there is no quick scoping either. Yes you can in a way quickly aim and get a headshot which I have done but its still difficult. But Marksmen rifles are really only effective with a headshot. And you wont get sniped by a shotgun either. Shotguns are powerfull but very limited by range. So for every situation there is a gun that excels. Which is why its a good idea to carry one of each weapon type to be prepared to everything and if you run out of ammo in your favorite gun.   So......The Dark Zone......I actually enjoy the Dark Zone, even with all the rogue agents trying to steal your loot. The gear you get there are far superior to gear outside the DZ. I have met more friendly agents than rogue. I have been killed by rogue agents and they really ♥♥♥♥ me off. But the feeling of revenge is even better!!! Extraction are a bit nerve racking.........you cant trust anyone. The guy that has helped you clear out the area could just as easy shoot you in the back, or you could shoot him first ;) But like I said, I havnt run into many people willing to risk going rogue. But we will see if that changes by the time im level 30.

Alright so lets get the bad out of the way first. The servers went down day 1, which was expected, and if you didn't expect it then you weren't thinking about it. Initially there was some super bad lag for bullets registering as hits on enemies, even in singleplayer, which was fixed when the servers came back up. There's occasional texture pop in even on high end cards. Essentially, if you look for something to be wrong with the game, you'll find it, probably pretty easily to be honest.  However, with all the negatives, I'm enjoying this game immensley. Some will complain about bullet sponge enemies and it not being realistic. That's fine, this game isn't really focused on that. It's more in the vein of a Tom Clancy: Borderlands in Third Person style gameplay. If you're looking for some fun coop with friends in a coop RPG shooter, this is a wonderful pick for it. Essentially, if you know what the game is before you get into it, or you played the beta, you already know what to expect, and honestly it's pretty good at what it does. It might not be flawless, but honestly I've not played a game that is, and sometimes there are bugs, as with just about every game. However, the positive coop/singleplayer experience I've had thus far completely outweighs them. If you watch the devs stream it, you can tell that they're genuinely proud of the game and enjoy it, and I can't help but say that I enjoy it as well. There have been minor frustrations (when the servers went down I got cut out in the middle of a 'long' mission, and had to repeat it multiple times) but all in all, I've had a blast. It's a Tom Clancy game, so you can come to expect a Tom Clancy story. (I've enjoyed all of them that I've played) in a RPG shell. It's wonderful, does it's job, kicks ♥♥♥, and brings you back for more.  with the negatives, I give it a 9.0/10, for the solid, enjoyable coop/singleplayer experience: Tom Clancy shelled Third Person RPG.

For seasoned players, certain AR graphical pointers can be turned off – such as the GPS navigation system. But for casual gamers and those starting out, these are why it is so easy to leap into the game without little preamble. The AR navigation line snakes its way through streets to mission points marked on the map or, if you are in building on a mission itself, to the next objective. You cannot get lost, basically.  In addition, whenever you are next to an item you can pick up, a barrier you can duck behind, or an object you can manipulate or use, you get a button indicator showing exactly what you need to press. Who needs the tutorials eh? So far, we’ve played a fair selection of different mission types, on our own and with a ragtag bunch of online acquaintances. Teams of up to four players can co-operatively take part in the missions, which you can make up in the safe houses dotted around, from friends or simply by checking out if others are available at that moment, but we didn’t feel punished by tackling objectives on our own (as much as we do in, say, Destiny). Taking on main and side missions solo is a harder pursuit for sure – even if you are sometimes helped by AI JTF agents – but there’s something to be said for giving yourself that kind of challenge. You can also up the difficulty level for tasks too, before you start each. As well as main story missions, which initially help expand and improve your base of operations, there are plenty of side missions dotted around the map. We’ve found them to be of fairly standard types and some can be quick to complete, including the hostage rescue and a base assault missions. That helps as, with the persistently online world, you won’t be able to pause and pick up later. If you want a quick bout of The Division, these are there for exactly that purpose, it seems. They also help you or your base level up more quickly. In gameplay terms, Ubisoft has presented a game that doesn’t really break much new ground, but works because of the familiarity. The duck and cover mechanics of The Division are essential and standard for many third-person shooters. Where this differs from many of its peers is that enemies are genuinely hard to take down. Thanks to the role-playing elements, enemies have stamina points rather than a set number of hits, so depending on what weapon you use, the modifications and your own skill set, each hit will cause a different amount of damage – which you see in numeric manifestations during battles. Enemies also hide behind cover and some have armour, so they are taken into account too.  In our several hours of play so far we’ve had to restart missions plenty of times because we’ve been overwhelmed by difficult to beat waves of bad guys who don’t just fold at the wave of an SMG. And that’s the way we like it. It’s just as well really as the game is a bit one-note in its tone – at least to the point where we’ve ended up in the game. Working out ways to dispatch foes using the talents and tools at your disposal is just about it. Missions have different objectives and goals, and exploration around New York is rewarded, but if you don’t like long, at times tricky armed battles, you’re barking up the wrong tree.

Most of the reviews you will read will either 'A' complain about server issues or complain about it's the same thing over and over again. While yes those things are true. The server issue only happen at release when NA gamers where allowed to play and was quickly fixed within an hour. The issue of doing the same thing over and over in a game is pretty much any game you play. Now on to the review.     Graphics:    The game looks gorgeous it really showcases what Manhattan would look like during a pandemic. From the Sun Light to the smoke everything looks great. BUT and it is a big BUT. What happen to the graphics we saw back at E3 several years ago? I mean I can honestly say it does look different and I bet a lot of it had to be because of the consoles. Even with the game's graphics not what they were showcased years ago you really need a high powered machine to get everything maxed. With that being said the graphics will not disappoint you trust me, but they are not what was advertised years ago.   9/10    Story:    The story revolves around an outbreak of an unknown virus that has been carried by money and infecting millions and millions of people. You and countless others who call themselves The Division are brought in to help bring peace and order during these times. They did a really good job telling the story of how it all started. Here is where it gets a little bit annoying. They have bits of information and backgrounds that is spread out all through Manhattan. Some of them are portrayed through the actual game world. (I really thought this was pretty cool) Some of the information you have to go into the cumbersome menu (More to that later) and view them but the menu system just leaves frustrated with the menus.(Ex. Scrolling, Multiple Menus to get to one bit of Information.) If you do take the time to go through those issues and read and investigate what is going on it is really decent story.   8/10    Gameplay:   Oh man I am loving the gameplay. Now I really love third person shooters. I also love the cover system in this game. If you hate anyone of those then this game is not for you. You will be going from cover to cover a lot. You will fight the same guys over and over again. Yes at higher difficulties they are bullet sponges. Having to group up on hard missions or even if you go solo is rewarding as hell after you beat that mission and get the loot. This is a loot shooter after all and you will be doing that constantly. The dark zone is where I think the game can shine for some and turn others away. You go to the dark zone to do PVP. In this zone you are not flagged as PVP until you attack another player and once you do you are now considered rouge for a few mins. This is where people will get upset if you are killed due to one of these rouges because when you do die you drop your loot and DZ(Dark Zone Currency) and they can pick it up. This works both ways though and I feel it really brings the game from the standard Capture the flag or death match type that we are all accustomed to. You do not have to do the PVP you can fight regular NPC’s in the Dark Zone. But you still do not know if any other player may want to shoot you in the back while you’re running to that extraction point. The Dark Zone does have limits you have to extract all the loot you get and you have limited inventory space. The extraction points is where the rouge system shines, most the time this is where they decide to cap you in the back while you are trying to extract your loot. Now there are some people who have stated that going rouge is not rewarding due to the death penalty and the rewards not giving you enough to go rouge or losing Dark Zone levels. I feel this can be patched and fixed at some point to make it more rewarding.  8/10    Audio:    Voice Chat enough said, besides that though the game does have great audio as well.     8/10     Final Thoughts:    A lot of people will compare this to Destiny and it has a lot of the same similarities but I played destiny and it was great for the first 20 levels. Then the loot drops stopped and you had to farm engrams or whatever and it was chore. Memories of shooting at a cave for hours. Ughh….. They finally came around and fixed some of those issues. The Division really isn’t the same game though it has the typical loot drops like Borderlands, Diablo and others. To me that it a huge plus. I also feel some of the issue and bugs will be ironed out after a few months or even weeks. As they seem to be fixing some of them as quickly as possible. They are very active in the Steam forums to let us know they are seeing what issues are present. You really need to give this game a shot and I feel you won’t regret it.    Final Score:  9

This game is in my opinion fantastic, but everyones is different so here is what you need to know to see if you will like the game. Do you like...    Good story?   Progression?   Wide Gear and Gun Variety? (I'm a bit of a gun guy and the diversity of weaponry on display is pretty incredible)   Challenging gameplay?   Risk? (The Dark Zone taps into the excitement of DayZ, where pvp is possible and dying constitutes a very real loss that will make you annoyed for about 20 minutes. You *can* lose all the gear you've collected on that specific run into the dark zone, however the loss is not so catastophic that you want to ragequit. Its just enough to keep that zone adrenaline fueled.)   If those things all sound good to you, you will like the game.   However!   There is  one  thing people complain about in this game, and I do give it some validity. Its something you need to be able to get over it in order to enjoy The Division.   This game is a MMO fps, and there are some   boss enemies[/b]  in this game.   These guys take a  lot  of punishment before dying, particularly in the Dark Zone. You, and your team, will have to headshot them multiple times, use multiple grenades, learn to split your forces to hit them in the back while one keeps his attention from behind cover etc in order to take them down, or your whole team will be wiped.  Some people find this silly, and I get it to a  certain extent , because in real life if you shoot someone in the head they are dead. But from a gameplay perspective there is no practical way to impliment challenging bosses in a MMOFPS other than giving them the ability to take a lot of punishment, otherwise every boss would just be dropped from 100 meters out by a guy with a sniper rifle.  It doesn't really bother me, and makes for some really great, challenging fights... but if boss enemies in an otherwise realistic MMO Fps are going to be a dealbreaker for you, then  do not get the game.    But... I can say I have had more fun in the Dark Zone in tense, paranoid interactions with other potentially hostile players than I've had gaming in about 10 years, so if you give this game a miss because of the high hitpoint boss enemies, it would be a shame.  Hope this helps you make up your mind about this game, good luck!  -Wolfsanker

Saying The Division is addictive is an understatement, it's one of those games where you say I'll pop on for an hour and the next thing you know 6 hours have whizzed by. Pros and Cons first, then a quick review.  Pros: + Excellent cover system which is easy to use, fluid and works well. Cover is a major part of any engagement in the game. + Combat is excellent, yes it's not a sim and enemies have health bars but this means fire fights can be intense at times. + AI is very well implemented. Enemies use cover well, try and flank you and retreat & regroup for full on attacks. + HUGE selection of weapons, mods, gear, skills and talents to customise you character with. + The city, it's amazingly detailed. A friend of mine who lives in New York was even impressed. + The atmosphere is extremely well done, from the litter strewn streets to over listening to peoples conversations about how they've fallen to a life of crime all adds to a very believable living world. + The graphics, yes there were some 'downgrades' from the E3 demo but most games add all the bells and whistles to E3 tech demos to get the interest built up and then they optimise. But the city looks amazing and the attention to detail is stunning. + Sound is done really well, everything from weather sound fx, npc's talking to each other, distant gun fire echoing through the street to the insults and taunts the enemies throw your way in combat. + Missions can be great fun and challenging especially on hard mode.  Cons: - Some of the side quests/encounters can get repetitive. - Character facial customisation is a little on the weak side and would have liked more options but the gear customising in game makes up for it. - Alot of the gear looks very similar, but as they are based on real world type items I guess one black beanie hat looks like another black beanie hat. - Upgrading the base of operations can be a little grindy with regards to earning the supply points.  Review:  Overall I am really enjoying the game, I played through the open beta and have racked up 7 hours so far in the live game. I read alot of the negative steam reviews about the servers being down on launch but I played for several hours before the servers went down and they weren't down for long. Yes I agree it's annoying when that happens and devs (all devs not just Ubisoft) should learn by now from past releases but giving a game a negative review because of a server crash seems silly to me, a game review should be on the game itself really.  Gameplay is great fun, especially with a few friends. Combat can be intense at times with some firefights lasting alot longer than you first thought they would because of the cover system being used well by both players and AI.  I'm not far enough into the story to comment too much on it, but so far it's fairly interesting.  PVP in the Darkzone is fun, and this is coming from someone who doesn't fully enjoy pvp much. But with the rogue system it makes every encounter with another player in the DZ a careful one, you never know wether you can trust the other person but don't want to be the one to fire first (unless you want to go rogue of course).  Is it the perfect game to end all games, no.... but what game is. What it is however is great fun, and what it sets out to do is done extremely well. I look forward to what Ubisoft brings to the game, especially hoping for more mission types/content with regards to sidequests/encounters.  Overall for me, a 9/10.

Now, if only I could stop thinking that I have a chainsaw attachment for my rifles...... like you do in a certain other 3rd person shooter I've been playing lately.  It took me two tries to get Uplay to login and from there I activated my key. This was around 1 a.m. , an hour after the game launched. My first time loading the game up, I got a black screen. Once I had restarted my PC, it worked fine the second time I launched it. From there, it was quite amazing. The graphics are breathtaking with a silky smooth framerate and very clear fidelity. I really like how the UI works, it's simple and clean. If you read the info, you won't have a problem knowing how to use it. The gunplay feels good, as well. It's similar to Gears of War, minus the heavy feel. I have finished the tutorial in Brooklyn.   So far, the negatives I've found are few. They don't really affect my enjoyment of the game but I'm not a picky guy. The story seems to be basically what you'd expect in this setting, complete with a silent protaganist. Actually, the characters I've met so far don't seem to have much character at all and their voice actors don't seem to have done anything special, either. So, this game's dressings are rather vanilla so far. The enemies seem to be able to take far more bullets than you can but that creates the challenge. Plus, this is an RPG, so you aren't going to be OP at the start.   Overall, The Division has left a very positive first impression on me. The gameplay itself, seems tight and I can feel the loot addiction starting up. A few issues getting it started at first are expected, so that didn't bother me either. To conclude, I am satisfied with this game.

As with most Ubisoft games, I fail to see the reason behind the vitriol. I came into  Tom Clancy’s The Division  expecting a solid, open world third-person shooter with light RPG mechanics and some novel online functionality. I have gotten just that. Am I missing something here?  My first impressions: some of the most fluent cover shooting I've experienced since  Spec Ops: The Line  and post-pandemic New York is as beautiful to wander as it is haunting, wonderfully immersive in its appropriate desolation.   The Division  is absolutely gorgeous to look at and surprisingly well-optimized out of the box; one of only three games out of hundreds I've been unable to max out on my current configuration, I average a solid 30 frames with a custom blend ranging between the high and ultra presets which, for me, is both impressive (for a two year-old notebook -- ASUS ROG G750JZ) and appropriate given the technical depth presented here.  Character creation is OKAY. Not good, not bad, but OKAY. It's serviceable. Personally I don't find the player models anywhere near as ugly as people have made them out to be. If anything I find my agent to be rather adorable -- an everyday woman on the job.  The plot is, for the most part, relatively unexplored and welcome territory for the medium. Storytelling, however, has been threadbare, so if that's a personal concern then this may not be the one you're looking for;  The Division  is gameplay-centric to its core. I think most everyone will be impressed by the opening cinematic, though!  Really enjoying the original score, too; the menu and combat themes are perfectly fitting.  There's been much hot air over server issues. Let me put this into perspective: they were back up by the time my preload was finished unpacking, something nearly unprecedented for a game with significant online functionality.  Overall,  Tom Clancy’s The Division  has been a fabulous addition to my Steam library, everything I wanted and then some. Is it a revolution in game design? Hardly, but for those of you with proper expectations in mind, I struggle to think of any genuine alternatives.

Hey. I rarely write reviews but here it goes. Sorry for bad English and also for the lack of PvP stuff, I'm just not interested in that for a moment. Not with ROR alive, anyway :> I wasn't going to buy this game, haven't even heard about it. But here we were raiding bugged as <censored> ops in SWTOR and someone said: 'Hey, we have to wait for 4.3 anyway since many people are going to try on this new MMO'. People kept talking about it and I've decided to give it a try. Side note: I normally don't play shooters (or semi-shooters) at all since I'm very bad at them but some time ago my husband wanted to play GTA 5 with me and I kinda liked it in the end. So I've got this game and been enjoying it so far. Now about what I like and dislike. + Modern and even better post-apocalyptic enviroment (♥♥♥♥ them elfs and magic).  + Running around and doing missions without seeing 3.14 people camping over same boss. But in a while I suppose it may become repetitive and boring.  + Doing hardmode operations solo - nothing like get your ♥♥♥ handed to you by some elite guys with flamethrowers. Although probably people with better aim and/or gear will just breeze through them. + Feeling of the world around you - from graphic design to random things you find like phone recordings, vids, etc. It really puts you there into the dying city and I'm feeling intrigued to know more about the outbreak. + ALL YOUR BASE ARE BELONG TO US!!! Seriously, I love having some place for myself in games even if it's not pretty, moreso if it can be upgraded and developed by you. Ahem, what do they say about women and nests :> + Class trinity. Pretty controversial, this one, but I'm from the crowd that likes it. It's not mandatory to have a healer or a tank in your party, but surely it will help. From what I've seen in skills, you can build support role too! + Easy role switching so i don't have to level an alt to try something different. Also skill development is interesting (not sure I've seen something like that in other games): you unlock them through upgrading your base, rather then simply levelling. Makes sense lore-wise too - I mean if you want better grenade you need better technology. + Fighting style: aiming, rolls, cover. Reminds me of Mass Effect somehow, but then again I haven't seen many shooters before. Now about bad things. - Most important: REGION LOCK and restricted language. Sorry dear Russian voice actors, but my ears are ♥♥♥♥ing bleeding each time I hear NPC's speak. Also yes I get it's New York but it's not Brighton Beach and it feels VERY wrong to play this in Russian. Breaks immersion tremendously :< Yes I get it our version is cheapier but lot of people would gladly pay more for original sound and interface, but guess what? It can't be done with region lock, not legally anyway. I love my country but this is not about that, it's about immersion. - Stability. Actually it's not that big of deal for me since I always have things to do if servers are down, but eh, money are paid and service must be available. - Map design. So, I'm used to those tunnel enviroments where you can go only one way (/target Bioware /wave) but it would be better to have truly open world where you can go into any building and see what's there. Even if there isn't anything significant. Recordings and pictures alone can do the trick if done right. E.g Elite Dangerous planetary landings aren't that great and planets are pretty dull, but it's enough to know you can land on some uncharted world 50.000LY away from home to feel more deep into this endless space. - Character customisation. Ugh. I just say that was the first time I've considered creating male character. First time. Ever. I don't mean there must be some pretty dolls with makeup (there's war going around, eh) but there must be more options. Also female faces look okay in character creator but ingame... (Disgusted noise by Cassandra Pentaghast).  - Endgame. I may be mistaken, but what do you do when you upgraded your base to the max and did all missions for 10+ times and not interested in PvP? Well, we'll see :)  Maybe something more but I'm tired typing :D Would I recommend this game? Yes. If the person has money to spare on probably short-lived fun. If they doesn't or if they want some long-term game to live in? No.

After playing for about 100 hours in the first month, the game quickly showed that it didn't have the legs. Obviously with a new release repetitive missions, and modes begin to show their teeth, however the loot system and resource gathering system were botched a few ways which ended up making progression extremely mind numbing, and it seemed that those with the patience to constantly grind had the advantage over any actually ability to get better via skill or thinking.  The match making for the raids was a nightmare, as those who weren't prone to communicating and being social(feels like 80% plus of the game, would rage quit after not showing very much effort to learn the Raid, and try to improve with the people who joined. The game should introduce a mode to train people on tactics, I mean, we are an elite group of 'solider' right, so why not create a game mode where people can earn points during leaderboard ladder systems by actually performing combat strategic activity’s. Like how fast can you get to a location in a room while using cover run. Laying suppressions fire, flanking enemies; you know just something that could help the masses improve within the game.  Anyway, the game is fun until you maxed out what you can do, and then the reward system falls of a cliff, and you will quickly realize that the excitement from doing or gaining minimum upgrades isn't worth the time sink. Some games do a great job of making that task feel almost worth it, however it isn’t up to that level with this title as of yet. Hopefully more content is released, as well as game modes. Not a bad game... just needs to quadruple the content, and add 3-4 more game modes... a few more classes, and reward team play.. And I’ll be back.

Sure, it's a mild annoyance to be kicked out like that, but it isn't a common issue.   Secondly, yes, the game is very grindy: go to A, kill him, go to B, kill her, and sure, sometimes, the enemies are OP AF and the run between A and B is long, but the visuals are amazing, the streets of this apocalyptic Manhatten. The city has many interiors to enter, places to explore, plenty of missions to keep you going. Mind you, I have't even entered the dark zone!  Now, the movement is a bit clunky, where the cover system is odd at times, and you can't even seem to jump down certain ledges. Main flaw of the game is the navigation of the rooftops: it is very artificial and the route is linear. It doesn't give much freedom for the player to roam the rooftops as they wish, and even jump off to kill themselves.  Now, for the storyline so far is pretty decent, but I really like the game because of it's upgradability for the main base as it gives a clearcut goal, clothings and to go on a hunt for them and the simple fact that it is not a bad freeroam game, as long as you don't go on rooftops, that is.  I highly recommend this game if it were a tad cheap, maybe on Steam sales, although it is not too shabby to buy for £40/$60.

Love this game, and hate the developers decision to release the game before they'd fixed the major technical issues.  Gameplay is much like assasins creed's urban game. Except much more action, which is awesome! I really loved what time I actually got to 'play' the game.   The gameplay is a heap of fun, and you can easily spend 100-200 hours playing. There is lots to do, with the freedom of open roaming. However, once you hit endgame, there's very little left to do.   Unfortunatly, for a game that is now officially Released, and out of Beta, it has a HUGE amount of technical failures. Crashes, incompatible with leading graphic cards, game bugs/glitches where you get stuck, or don't get the reward from missions or vendors. Lots of graphical malfunctions (most likely due to poor performance optimization).  The PVP is horribly unbalanced, as is the gear aquasition. Hackers and griefers benefit greatly, and easily. Don't even bother entering the Dark Zone (PVP area) without being level 30+ with great gear, you WILL be one-shot constantly by other players.   I also found the Support for the game incredibly lacking. There is no clear/easy way to make a support ticket. The uplay support feature didnt' work for me at all, as the site wouldn't let me enter anything at all in the 'Product' field of the report, and wouldn't let me submit the report without entering something in the Product field. (hence, unable to even file a support ticket).  The game itself is fantastic! Briliant concept, lots of fun. But due to the problems mentioned, I would NOT recommend this game at the moment. I would recommend waiting a few months until they actually FINISH the game, and buy it then. It should never have been released in the state it is, it's still be BETA.

Tom Clancy's The Division is yet another maths game. It seems to be aimed at male preteens who find it too boring to learn math. The pace of the game is well-balanced, with players solving math problems interspersed with dramatic action scenes.  The protagonist, a very Alec-Baldwin-ny Jack Ryan, is tolerable enough, but the constant application of witty one-liners and the insertion of beautiful female characters into the plot does not a James Bond make. That said, the storywriting is competent enough, but few of the characters seem particularly likeable, and I felt a growing sense of apathy in the game, most noticable by the time I had defused the bomb in the President's briefcase. The main exceptions I can draw here are Mister Glozov, Jack Ryan's witty GRU counterpart, and Madame D'orangé, the scantily-clad dominatrix first seen at the end of 'Part 3'.  Sometimes the action scenes can seem a little jarring, as the scene cuts from dramatic sequences to solving maths problems. Barrelling down the corridors of the Kremlin as explosions crash around you is all well and good, but when a math problem appears mid-sprint in the centre of your screen, it does tend to take the player out of the action. That said, there is still something very satisfying about solving a complex differential equation and seeing the result play out in front of you.  I played this game through by myself, and managed a good twelve hours of gametime. I did not devote too much time to the 'side missions' and 'odd jobs', but I understand that these alone can provide another three-hundred-plus hours of content. You will probably want to undertake these side ops as the game progresses, if only to witness the changes that occur to your home area, the rather blandly-named 'Base Alpha'. While I did not undertake any of the side missions that appeared after 'Act 2', I was particularly happy when the Drama-Cola vending machines appeared, not to mention the Japanese stripper bar.  Oh, sorry. Forget about all that.  This game is actually a multiplayer, third-person shooter with brilliant graphics and MMO elements.

Review based upon beta and early launch.  This is an open world RPG shooter, meaning:  Open world: You are free to go where you want on the map, the game is not blocking you from going places that are too deadly. And the map is a large chuck of New York whick is mostly free roam (some areas do requite a load, like the player versus player area). Exploring the map is rewarded with lore e.t.c. While moving about there are random encounters of various kind, these can be ignored or not, depending on what you feel like.  RPG: Your character gains experience points that can be used to improve and acquire various abilities, like healing and using a (physical) riot shield. Loot/rewards are level based, so an improved item may not be useable right away.  Shooter: This is the base game mechanics against enemies, along with grenades and any abilites that have been acquired. It is also covered based, so using cover to advance/retreat to improve survival and supressing of the enemy is an important tactic. The weapons have slots, with options to slot in upgrades (laser sight, larger magazine e.t.c. if you have them) that modifies the stats on them.  The graphics in the game is great and very realistic, the atmosphere of the city is very convincing. However, since they did not do a complete city, parts of it ends somewhat abruptly and can break immersion as it obvious to see where the map ends. The occasional building and underground area does help to make the city feel more real, as well as offer alternative routes to locations.  Character movement feels a bit slugish when moving about and changing directions. Disengaging from cover can bit a bit wonky, as well as using some abilities. Quick double press for the heal abilities rarely worked for me and it switched to the throw version of it, which is not something you want to struggle with during intense battles.  Your base gives access to crafting (remains to be seen if it worth it, given the excelent loot from the PvP area), and new/better abilities when the base is upgraded. Upgrading is done with specific materials, which can be rewards from some missions.  The mission area/encounters design seems rather lazy, in that you either defend against several waves of enemies at a location, and/or go through several areas where one of more waves will appear, often with a boss encounter at the end. To me this is the biggest flaw in the game so far, it is very predicable what and when it will happen, only the number of waves and enemy type is a 'surprise'. Granted it is limited what they can do while keeping it realistic, still gives that part of the game a meh feeling.  tl;dr If you like shooters with some strategy/cover elements and the ability to roam freely in a city, this game might be for you.

You cannnot no matter what planning ahead you do prevent server slams when millions of people are loading onto then ALL At ONCE.  Some people can not be satisfied no matter what and never pay attention to mininum PC requirements and complain when their 'old' trusty 4 year old PC cant seem to hang with the latest game.  VERY BASIC REVIEW:  Graphics in this game are insane on the highest setting (and even lower settings are nice) My PC is a mid range gaming computer and is playing Divison at a smooth 60 fps. The snow? Collects on you as it falls, the fog can cause you to turn a corner and BOOM right into some bad guys. Its a very pretty game, but you have to have the PC horsepower to see it.  The cover and fire motion is fluid and you must master it to keep from getting shot to pieces. One mission was inside a mall (I played solo) with a tactic of cover and fire and with well placed grenades and the ability to throw out the auto turrent I was able to defeat the mobs along with veteran NPC's and a super bad guy with a flame thrower. It was not a cake walk. NPC's will flank you and others will provide suppressive fire and move on you. The NPC's that charge you are like drug fueled crazy's that will go down easy with head shots but if you get hit POW!  Some missions have a sniper that does crazy damage and you have to fire and move to get closer or pull out your own rifle and reach out and touch them.   Your character can collect and mix and match gear to have his or hers or idenity and stand out from others.   The missions to get a working base up are fun, story driven and make you feel like you have a purpose other than mindlessly just shooting everything. And remember this, you can do whatever you want. Dont feel like doing a mission? Do some quick side missions. Collect intel, phone logs, video logs etc etc etc. I personally like to listen to the phone logs they give a human side story to the pandemic doom. Collect weapon parts, and other material to make some good weapons and gear.  NPC's hang out of windows to praise you and or yell at you. Dont like them? Fire a few rounds and they retreat inside their apartment and turn the lights off lol. I like that kind of detail.  Did I say no loading screens? NONE even in the Dark Zone in and out, nadda, zero, NONE.  The cleaners are literally a blast to destroy. Hit them in their tanks and watch them go boom.   Anyway very basic review but this game is simply just plain old fun for me.

My group of 3 came across 2 groups of 4 at an extraction area and since mics are all open we started chit chatting with one another, all the while all 3 groups constantly maneuvering around to ensure no one could get the drop on their group then a shot and a grenade out of nowhere. A good Game.  Don't read all the negative reviews and think the game isn't good it depends on the people, what they want to play.  If you want a gread story and universe to dive in this isn't the best game for you.  But if you like shooting and the MMO genre it's the game for you. The goal is to play the story and get level 30 after this the online part get's more and more important, the main goal for you is gearing up. To dungeons or Darkzone.(i recommend darkzone because dungeons are to difficult for fresh lvl 30) The concept of the Game is a bit like Diablo 3. You run from Boss to Boss in the Darkzone, and loot everything, and check if it's better than yours and if a legendary weapon dropps (yellow one) and you like it you are very happy.  Grinding for gear is an essance of the Game, to do the challengs dungeons (lvl 30 dungeons in lategame) better and maybe to do some PvP in the Darkzone.  It's like Diablo the game with the loot.  Also the combat system of the game is great for this reason it doesn't get boring for me even after nearly 60 hours of playtimg it makes stil a lot of fun. Every weapons is different and the mods you can equip the weapon makes it better and let it feel better.  So if you like a Game like this buy it, if you need a Game with great Story and no lootgrinding and don't like the online part of the Game than don't buy it because you won't be happy with the Game. For me the game is perfekt one shooter mmo wich is online and worth playing.

First off I'll say I dislike shooters. Most of them are run and gun with no point to it.  The Division was recommended to me by a friend. I got into beta, I had a great time. After beta ended I spent a couple of weeks thinking about it before I pre-ordered.  Don't go into this game thinking it's like Black Ops or any other FPS. It isn't. It's not a blood bath and racking up body count. There is a story. And it is fantastic.   What I Liked:    Graphics where great even on medium.    I am running a nVidia 480, and the game runs well on medium. So optimization! Runs smooth!   The story elements, the echo system is awesome, and you use it to review sites and investigate sites in your side quests.   Once you get to your Base of Operations you start to unlock and upgrade it. It adds a great feeling of atmosphere.   you can specialize for a certain type of play. The are no classes, but you can build your character to play like a medic, sniper, scout, or assault.   I love the weapons system, and the upgrade and customization of it.   other elements like helping out civilians and getting random rewards is great, just adds more feeling of the in-game world.    What I didn't like:     The cleaner faction uses fire element as there primary damage source. I think that fire damage might be a little bit unbalanced, not even a chance to run before you are toast.   in between each objective when you and your squad, or just yourself, are traversing the map. There is very little to do. The bad guys that spawn are rare, and always the exact same.   The cash rewards vs gear and weapon cost is off. I saved all my cash up until level 10. Still couldn't afford a level 10 sniper rfile.   Some people might wonder why I didn't mention bugs or the server downtime on launch day. Simply put, no developer ever has gotten launch day perfect. Even the mighty Blizzards botched almost every Wow expansion release.   I've got around 15hrs total time played. And just one bug. No glitches. No stuck in the terrain.  EDIT: Hit lvl 30. Discovered you are forced into the Dark Zone for the rest of the HE crafted SET (Power ilvl 31). Dropped HE are lvl 30. So the crafted stuff is the endgame stuff, and better. But you forced into PvP (Seal Clubbing) to get it. Everyone @ lvl 30 is thrown together regardless of rank or gear. Rogues don't fight Rogues. Rogues murder players grinding to Rank 50 (yes rank 50) to get the BP's too complete the set that the BoO started. So if you want to be geared for PvE you must endure being merced (Murdered) in PvP. I don't recommend this game. The changes they have made since launch have turned the entire experience Toxic.  EDIT: In 1.4 I returned to the game. I have to say the changes to game have been tremendous. I have been playing for a couple of days and I'm having a great time. I love the changes and additions since March. It took them a while to get there heads out, but its definitely better.

As of the time of this review the game has become unplayable. Due to the constant match making bugs (most notably quick finding a group for an activity and the activity will not start), physics system failures (one layer of the world failing to render causing you to fall through the world), and other bugs all end game activities other than the Dark Zone are unplayable. Due to these persistent bugs I was unable to successfully join any daily activities for two days straight). The Dark Zone has turned into a giant gank fest of rogue agents constantly ruining your time in the Dark Zone. Unless you have a complete 4 man team it isn't worth the effort. In short, until this game receives some major fixes don't waste your time or your money. Especially if you are a player that tends to be a loner.  1.1 Update: The developers have not fixed any structural problems with the game but have only introduced more with this update. Due to an exploit that allowed people to speed farm top tier gear a massive balance problem caused by this exploit has made the situation far worse in The Dark Zone. The developers have not taken any definitive action to address the situation other than patching the exploitable bug. The developers are not doing their due diligence in QA and not taking definitive action to clean up their mess.   There are also many positive changes made to the game with 1.1 update. That said due to the lack of due diligence in QA, and allowing exploiters to benefit from their actions with no serious repercussions I still do not recommend this game unless you are willing to put up with a game in this state.  1.4 Update: Massive took the time to clean the game up top to bottom. All end game activities of any kind now reward you with ample opportunities for upgrades. Game balance is much improved. Game stability is much improved. The game has finally turned the corner and is now fun and rewarding to play. The game no longer feels like an unpolished beta product and now feels like a polished release. As a result of all the changes I'm changing my review to a thumbs up.

Tom Clancy's The Division has been through a roller coaster of quality. From the buggy and disorganized release, very few enemy types, poor loot tables, and terrible PvP, to the recent 1.4 patch that fixed the loot tables, balanced and buffed skills, weapons and armor sets, and brought me back to the game!  While 1.4 makes Solo Play not impossible anymore, you would be wise to grab at lease 1 buddy to help you out. The game lacks variety in enemies with a total of 4 factions opposing you. Cleaners (hazmat psychos trying to burn out the infection with flame throwers) Rikers (escaped convicts) LMB (private military contractors) and the gang members looting corpses and stores.  Teamwork and communications are vital in this game as you and your friends buff each other, heal each other, and revive each other constantly! Keep your skills varied among your friends and assign roles as to who does what. A designated medic is always nice, but its also everyone's job.   It may seem weird regular people are sweating numbers as you shoot them, but trust me, its a fun game. Don't overstep your boundaries though, as this game can be unforgiving... especially in the Dark Zone, the game's designated PvP area with the best loot  All and all i definitely recommend this game to anyone who likes destiny or casual team based games
