When The Divison was first announced at Ubisoft's 2013 E3 press conference I could not have been more hyped for everything I imagined this game would be. Did it live up exactly to the hype of the trailer? No. That being said it got really damn close.  There are so many minor things that draw me into this game that aren't even noticed by so many. The way the snow builds on your character when the snowfall gets heavy. The way the explosion and bullet sounds leads you towards combat so well. The audio cues in combat, while they can often be repetitive, actually bring something to the encounter, ex. an Alex saying he's moving forward, or how when you retreat they actually call it out to their buddies so they move forward. I sat in Skype with my friends talking for hours about the minor details that I just love about this game and I could go on for several paragraphs about these little things that make The Division feel alive.  Most people seem to be stuck up on either 'Ew it's Ubisoft and uses UPlay' or how repetitive the content is. While both have some validation because Ubisoft has made some mistakes in the past, and the content can get repetitive, I don't think either are a slight in the context of what we have as the current product. I can't say how much of a hand Ubisoft has had in The Division but Massive has done an amazing job at putting their game together, listening to community feedback and actually taking action on it. We've already seen a few cases of them listening to the community and patching it in the first week. UPlay doesn't really add or detract from the gameplay, so move on.   As for the content being repetitive, it can be. As someone who looked at this as sort of a half step between MMO and single player RPG, it's completely what I expected. Much like Destiny or Diablo or Borderlands, any kind of loot grind game generally seems to stay the same throughout the entire thing. There are variations on the enemies you fight in all of the titles, but overall the gameplay doesn't change and that's exactly the same thing for The Division. There's several different enemy factions which feel pretty unique from each other despite being all human enemies. As well the last boss of the game shakes things up pretty heavily, though it's disapointing it's the only boss like this in the game, from what we've seen from the trailers of the upcoming updates, we'll likely see more of this type of gameplay.  Overall if you enjoy loot driving, MMO style games, it's worth taking a look.

Horrible Ubisoft servers - Tom Clancy's The Error Code.  Repetitive missions.  6/10  --------------------------------------------------------------  This is an update for the review after 53 hours of gameplay. I still encounter game errors and the connection problems are still frequent especially during the night when people start palying division after returning home.   However, the game is worth trying if you are a fan of open world action game, and would like to have a glance of the beautiful NYC after the bio-attack.

I'm 28 hours in, and have played maybe 1/4 of my time grouped, the rest solo. The game is largely about finding out what the deal is with what is happening, and retaking New York. As such, expect a lot of combat vs thugs, and researching/finding 'clues'. It can seem somewhat repetative, but I found the combat to be fun, and like how the use of cover works in the game. I have had a couple issues where I couldn't seem to get out of cover, but that could have been due to me slamming keys on the keyboard in a panic because I was flanked by a thug.  The AI works the same in most battles, with the exception of a few scripted battles. Essentially the hand to hand guys just rush at you. They don't even try to use cover. (Too bad. They would have been really something if they attempted to use cover to get to you.) The regular mobs tend to move forward, using cover, and engage you. Some of them try to flank. This works well and forces you to maintain situational awareness or you will end up with slugs in your back. The snipers hang back and snipe, which is what you would expect. A little more movement from them to alternate sniping position would be nice as they're easy to pick off at leasure once you kill their friends. The bosses seem to act mostly the same as the regular mobs, making handling them only sleightly harder since they have a ton more HP. Overall, AI is passable, but could be better.  Missions - there's a few different types, but it boils down to 'Conquer', 'Conquer and Hold', 'Investigate the things' or 'Go get/do/push the thing, repeat doing this to the other things nearby'. The different locations help with this, but in a game that is supposed to run several seasons, they had better improve on this somehow or most of us aren't going to go much beyond season 1, if we even go that far.  There are a few different types of weapons in the game, which allow you to tailor your character to your play style which is nice. I usually found I had enough money to buy a couple nice items now and then to fill in the holes. I am running blues with a few greens and things seem to be going well for me. Crafting can also help you fill in a couple holes. Most of my stuff comes from drops though, which is as it should be in my oppinion. Weapons upgrades are nice.  Character advancement is pretty easy and lets you tailor things to your liking. Nothing amazing here, but it works, and stays out of the way when you're busy shooting thugs. By this I mean, it doesn't throw things in the way of combat when you happen to advance something in the middle of combat. It knows you'll get to it later. (It does tell you you leveled, but not in any way that disrupts combat.)  The story is interesting, but the game starts things out feeling high intensity and that every moment counts. Once you get beyond the tutorials you realize there's no real need to hurry, and the story starts to feel like background noise to a fun MMOFPS experience. Would have liked the feeling of intensity and need to have continued.  Graphics are nice. Occasional lighting issues, but they don't happen often. I fell through the world once but was teleported back to base and was able to resume my mission easy enough. At least it handled it gracefully.  UI has a learning curve, but once you figure it out, it works.  I've started playing a bit in the dark zone PVP area. Put bluntly, this area can be brutal. Going at it solo? Plan to die a few times and have some of the stuff you got taken from you. There really should be a way to get the best gear other than going to this area. Uncontrolled PVP means anybody can come up on you and kill you at any time. And they will do this. I've had guys waiting for me to finish my PVE combat so they could hit me after I get my new stuff or when I'm hurt from combat. It's just a really tough place to be, even with friends. Not for the faint of heart. I think they're going to need to make alternate ways of getting the best gear, or make some changes to how the DZ works else it's going to end up the domain of the people who like that sort of thing, and the rest of us will be stuck with mostly blues and greens for gear.  All in all, it's an interesting game with a few problems, but quite a bit of fun. If you liked Borderlands, you'll probably like this game too. I might recommend waiting for a sale to get the base game, but either way it has the potential for hours and hours of entertainment.

Very glad I gave it a second chance. This review is mostly for players who maybe played at launch and are considering going back, I mostly just talk about the improvements they've made and why they make the game worth coming back, not so much about the game itself for newcomers. I played the game at launch on PS4 and really enjoyed it for a couple of weeks, but once I hit the endgame it quickly felt shallow and got old immediately. Then the first DLC and major patch hit and it became an unplayable mess; the dark zone (the only PvP offering at the time) became a complete waste of time, the first incursion was laughable compared to the destiny style shooter raids they were being compared to, and so many bugs were introduced hackers were everywhere, legit players were getting banned for no reason when ubisoft overcompensated, and for months the only updates were addressing these issues and no balancing or loot tweaks made the endgame any more exciting so there was no reason for me to go back and I figured the game was dead.  I heard the game was picking up steam again after patch 1.4 as I'm sure a lot of people did, and so when Steam had the game free for a weekend I gave it another shot (I wouldn't have paid, but frees free so why not). Well it's hard to really pinpoint what they fixed because it's definitely the same game I played before, but man it was so much more fun than the first time around. Somehow the loot drops feel better without being too saturated with overpowered stuff, the bosses are still bullet spongy as is the style of game, but fights don't feel absurdly long like they did. The bugs are all ironed out (except for a rather annoying one where your character grays out when changing clothes and gear sometimes) and once I hit max level on the new character and hit the endgame again it's definitely noticeable that they've focused heavily on adding and expanding existing endgame content in the first two DLCs and content drops since launch. There are tons of daily and weekly missions or side quests, crafting missions and rewarding log book style rotating quests, seek and destroy bounty missions, and the more difficult incursions they keep adding. They're still nowhere near Destiny's epic raids and certainly not MMO raids, but they're decently difficult without being impossible for a pick up group with no mics. Overall the game feels much more dense when it was very light on content before, and with the bugs and breaks fixed up its become very addicting the last week or so and I can see it keeping me entertained for quite some time not even coutning the multiple DLC drops planned.

(not sure why it is saying product recieved for free, I did not check this box but cannot remove it)  Ohh how I wish The Division launched in its current state.  As of its most recent patches, it is now the game it should have been. A gun based diablo with lots of loot, lots of options on how to play, and a devastated but oddly beautiful post viral attack New York.   Gone is the absurd bullet spongeyness of enemies. With the nerfing of their health pools, enemies now do more damage. Side note, thankfully shotgunners are not nearly as potent as they used to be despite this. The changes help in creating an intense fire fights, and a much greater need for strategic use of cover.  Hitting max level is just the start of the ride, now loot drops plentifully, enough to let you try out the different diablo 3 like sets and build differnt kits. Some are still stronger than others, but you have options like never before. A torment like world system that features weekly and daily kill targets atop dungeon like missions, adding more replayability and options for getting better gear.  The survivor DLC, features a fun, roguelike, mission that throws you into a blizzard bound New York. Chosing between either PVE or PVE, you are left scrounging for gear and survival necessities to make it out alive with loot. Granted if you die you still are rewarded, but once you start getting into the dark zone you can find some very nice rewards for your normal game.  This is some strange child between a Rainbow Six styled cover shooter meets an MMO. Fun with friends, a fun co-op fest awaits for those willing to try and brave its waters after its rocky launch.   In its current state, I do reccomend it. Pleasantly surprised by the changes, makes me hope if they carry through with a plan for a sequel, they take these design decisions and improve upon it.

Due to mostly negative feedback from early adopters I waited 9 months before delving into 'The Division', and was glad I did. It appears that many of the annoying quirks have now been addressed & bugs patched up making this game a more refined playing experience. It'll take a few hours of play time to find your feet in this open-world RPG shooter/looter, but your persistance will be rewarded to an addictive & atmospheric post-pandemic world. The realistic sites of Manhatten & wintery weather conditions are staggering in places that get more apparant as the blizzards & snow drifts close in reducing visibility to almost zero. Then there's the myriad of places to go visit, items to buy / loot, and missions to embark on. The real selling point of this game is visiting the eerily tense 'Dark Zone' where the rules of the game change. All the best gear is found there, so you'd be wise to make friends by joining squads & revive those in need if you want to survive long enough to extract your plunder from under the prying eyes of treacherous rouge players who'll kill you for your loot. Yes, aspects of this game require you grind alot for decent gear & high powered bosses soak up bullets like a sponge, but it still feels rewarding. I've waited ages to play a game as immersive as this, and rate it almost as good as the 'Left 4 Dead' games.

After seeing the trailer waited for the game with much anticipation. Finally bought it from the winter sale, full goodies pack. The game disappears in start, the game starts but in windowed mode even though full screen is enabled in the settings, the game starts but crashes during loading the current play, something in the background(uPlay?) crashes and the game freezes, the game crashes on exit.. I mean come on, 100 bucks on retail and you get this?  The loading time is a major hassle and after it has loaded and 'connected' I cross my fingers that it doesn't crash.  Actual gameplay is mostly just running to a checkpoint and shooting constant spawning gangbangers while trying to avoid getting hit, much what I expected but the prospect of exploring New York with amazing graphics makes up a lot. On PC you get to experience deaths due to control issues, many buttons to handle in a fire fight and the stats(health) are displayed so that you have trouble seeing if you are going to die especially if the camera changes stance. This should be stated in cat size letters on it's own box that you can not in any circumstances play it without an active internet connection.
